questions.text: Which of the following is true about global warming?

choices.text: CO2 is the major greenhouse gas
Kyoto Protocol called for 10% reduction in emission of greenhouse gases

questions.solution:
Carbon dioxide is the major greenhouse gas.

Greenhouse gases include:

  • Water vapour
  • Carbon dioxide
  • Methane
  • Tropospheric ozone
  • Nitrous oxide
  • Chlorofluorocarbons (non-natural)

Tropospheric ozone and chlorofluorocarbons are also important greenhouse gases. Water vapour is the most abundant greenhouse gas, but the water vapour produced directly by human activity contributes very little to the greenhouse effect. Hence, its emissions have not been estimated.

Greenhouse gases lead to global warming, which is the major cause of climate change. Climate change accelerates species extinction on Earth. 22nd of April is observed as Earth Day.

Related Pearl: Greenhouse Effect

  • Certain gases in the atmosphere absorb some of the upward-going, long-wave radiation after it has left the Earth’s surface
  • These gases are known as greenhouse gases (GHGs) or radiatively active gases (RAGs)
  • These gases then emit longwave radiation in all directions, the downward going portion of which add to the radiation arriving at the Earth’s surface and raise the equilibrium temperature.
  • In this entire process, the Earth acts as an effective insulator and the overall process is known as Greenhouse effect.
  • The most important natural GHGs are water vapour, carbon dioxide, methane, tropospheric ozone and nitrous oxide and non-natural GHGs are chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs).
  • Stratospheric ozone is not harmful and doesn’t contribute to the greenhouse effect
  • Greenhouse effect has a role in global warming which is the average rise in global temperature leading to change in climate patterns.
  • The Kyoto Protocol is an internal agreement linked to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change by which its Parties set internationally binding emission reduction targets. The Parties committed to reduce GHGs by 18 percent in period between 2013 and 2020.
  • The Paris Agreement central aim is to strengthen the global response to the threat of climate change by keeping a global temperature rise this century well below 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels and to pursue efforts to limit the temperature increase even further to 1.5 degrees Celsius. It deals with greenhouse gas emissions mitigation, apdaptation and finance starting in the year 2020.
  • The Montreal Protocol is related to the depletion of the atmospheric ozone layer, which is protective.

questions.text: What is the provision of preventive, curative, and promotional health services to every individual called?
questions.solution: Comprehensive health care as stated by the Bhore committee means giving integrated preventive, curative, and promotional health care to every individual, irrespective of their ability to pay.

questions.text: Which agency of the United Nations has the following logo?

choices.text: United States Agency for International Development

questions.solution:
The given logo is of the World Bank.

It helps less developed countries raise their living standards with economic support. The allocation of funds is decided by its Board of Governors.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about reverse triage?

choices.text: Classifying the victims based on the severity of their injuries and their survival with treatment
Color coding is done with red as the highest priority.

questions.solution:
Reverse triage is a situation where the less injured are treated earlier than the ones that are injured more.

This is used in wars and military settings, where soldiers may need to return to the field of battle soon after treatment.

It is also done when there is a scarcity of medical resources after a disaster.

questions.text: Centiles divide data into ____ equal parts?
questions.solution: Centiles divide data into 100 equal parts.

questions.text: After how many days of injection does a yellow fever vaccination certificate is valid?
questions.solution:
Validation of yellow fever vaccination starts from 10 days from the day of vaccination to a lifetime (recently ammended).

The Yellow fever vaccination certificate is valid beginning 10 days after administration of YF vaccine for primary vaccine recipients; this corresponds to the time at which the majority of vaccine recipients demonstrate immunity. 

India is a “yellow fever receptive area “.

If no certification is available then it is advised to Quarantine the person for a period of 6 days (Incubation period)

questions.text: What is the most common cause of injury-related death?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of injury-related deaths are road traffic accidents, followed by suicide.

According to the World Health Organisation (WHO), trauma is a major cause of death and disability across the world. Every year, 17th October is celebrated as World Trauma Day to highlight the increasing rate of accidents and injuries, across the globe and the need to prevent them.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a demographic process?
questions.solution: Demographic processes include fertility, mortality, marriage, migration, and social mobility.

Charaka is the father of Indian medicine. He wrote the Charaka Samhita.

questions.text: Specificity of a screening test is the ability of a test to detect ____
questions.solution:
Specificity of a screening test is the ability of the test to identify correctly those who don’t have the disease or the true negatives.

Sensitivity of a screening test is the ability of the test to identify correctly those who have the disease.

questions.text: All of the following statements about diabetes insipidus are true, except:
questions.solution:
In diabetes insipidus, hypernatremia is observed in the affected patient.

Low levels of vasopressin lead to the excretion of a large amount of diluted urine. This loss of water from the body leads to hypernatremia.

Related Pearl: Water Deprivation test in Diabetes Insipidus

Procedure: Start the test at 4 am by checking the baseline urine osmolality. Deprive the patient of water till 12 pm (8 hours), and then re-check urine osmolality. 

  Urine osmolality before water deprivation Urine osmolality after water deprivation Urine osmolality after desmopressin administration
Normal  Normal  Increases No change
Central DI Low No change >50% increase from baseline
Nephrogenic DI Low No change <10% increase from baseline
Primary polydipsia Low Increases No change


Note: Normal urine osmolality- 500-850 mOsm/L

questions.text: In a suspected case of pheochromocytoma, which of the following would you avoid while making a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Biopsy and FNAC should be avoided in patients with pheochromocytoma, as it is a highly vascular tumor. 

CT and MRI have similar sensitivity but T2-weighted MRI with gadolinium contrast is the optimal test for diagnosis. MIBG (metaiodobenzylguanidine) scintigraphy can be used to localize the tumor if both CT and MRI are negative.

Genetic testing may be performed as nearly 40% of the tumors are associated with familial syndromes like VHL, neurofibromatosis, and MEN2.

Note: In cases of malignant pheochromocytoma, biopsy may be indicated to confirm adrenal gland metastasis in other sites.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the casualty with confusion, vomiting, and abdominal pain. His blood sugar levels are 421 mg/dl and urine ketones are 3+. He is started on IV normal saline and insulin infusion. Which of the following should he be monitored for?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis, which is treated with insulin infusion. Insulin causes an intracellular shift of K+ ions resulting in a decreased extracellular K+ ion concentration. This results in hypokalemia.

Non-diabetic clinical applications of insulin include:

  • Treatment of hyperkalemia
  • To determine the functions of the anterior pituitary 
  • To examine the completion of truncal vagotomy

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in tumor lysis syndrome?
questions.solution:
Hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia, is seen in tumour lysis syndrome (TLS). 

It is caused by the destruction of a large number of rapidly proliferating neoplastic cells. It most commonly occurs after the initiation of chemotherapy. It is characterized by:

  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Hypocalcemia 
  • Acidosis
  • Acute renal failure

The management of TLS includes:

  • Aggressive hydration
  • Allopurinol 
  • Urinary alkalinization with sodium bicarbonate(Only advisable if rasburicase is not readily available. The level of calcium should be serially monitored)
  • Rasburicase - recombinant urate oxidase.

questions.text: A patient with a fungal infection was started on amphotericin B. Within a few days he started complaining about decreased urine output. On examination, it revealed muddy brown casts in urine. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Muddy brown casts are seen in acute tubular necrosis which is a type of intrinsic renal failure. Epithelial casts and granular casts can also be seen in acute tubular necrosis.

Casts in Urine

  • Hyaline cast: Normal physiological conditions, fever, exercise, prerenal failure
  • RBC cast: Glomerular injury
  • WBC cast: Pyelonephritis, interstitial nephritis
  • Muddy-brown granular cast: Acute tubular necrosis
  • Broad cast: Chronic renal failure

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

questions.text: A patient with CKD(chronic kidney disease)  is found to have normal kidney size on ultrasonography. The diagnosis which is LEAST likely is
questions.solution:
Hypertension-associated CKD, which usually presents with shrunken kidneys.

The finding of bilaterally small kidneys supports the diagnosis of CKD of long duration. but there are few exceptions,
Chronic kidney diseases with normal size kidneys are:

  • Diabetic nephropathy (where kidney size is increased at the onset of diabetic nephropathy)
  • Amyloidosis
  • HIV nephropathy.

questions.text: A  45-year old male presents with bilateral flank pain, gross hematuria. He has a family history of autosomal polycystic kidney disease. How many cysts should be present in the kidneys to diagnose him with ADPKD?

choices.text: At least 2 cysts in each kidney
At least 3 cysts in each kidney
At least 4 cysts in each kidney
Even a single cyst in each kidney

questions.solution:
2 cysts in each kidney should be present to make the diagnosis of ADPKD.

Diagnosis in ADPKD is generally made using the USG based diagnostic criteria, the Ravine’s criteria:

Age (in years) Imaging findings
15 - 39  Total of ≥3 cysts, unilateral or bilateral
40 - 59 ≥2 cysts in each kidney
≥ 60  ≥ 4 cysts in each kidney

questions.text: An adolescent boy presents with yellowish discoloration of sclera. His liver function tests reveal conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and normal liver enzyme levels. Liver biopsy revealed an accumulation of dark melanin like pigment in the hepatocytes. What is the probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with dark pigment deposition (image below) in the liver. These features are suggestive of Dubin Johnson syndrome.

In Dubin Johnson syndrome (DJS) there is defective excretion of conjugated bilirubin and various compounds like epinephrine metabolites causing the liver to appear black.

Rotor syndrome also has conjugated hyperbilirubinemia but there is no pigmentation of the liver.

Gilbert and Crigler-Najjar syndromes are characterized by unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Related Pearl: Rotor syndrome vs Dubin johnson syndrome

  Rotor syndrome Dubin Johnson syndrome
Inheritance Autosomal recessive Autosomal recessive
Defect Organic anion transporting polypeptide  defect.(OATP1B1,OATP1B3) Multi drug resistance protein (MRP )2 mutation
Biopsy Normal Black pigmentation
Conjugated bilirubin Elevated Elevated
Kernicterus absent absent

questions.text: What is the first marker to rise in a patient with acute hepatitis B?
questions.solution:
The first virologic marker to rise in acute hepatitis B is HBsAg i.e., Hepatitis B surface antigen. It is detectable in serum within 1–12 weeks of infection. Usually, HBsAg becomes undetectable 1–2 months after the onset of jaundice. If it persists beyond 6 months, it indicates chronic hepatitis B.

However, very rarely, patients may have an HBsAg negative status even during active infection due to infection with escape mutant HBV. These escape mutants have mutations within the S gene and they are known to be responsible for occult hepatitis B infections.

questions.text: A young patient with Hepatitis E virus infection develops acute liver failure. Which of the following scores can be used in assessing the prognosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient with acute liver failure, MELD score and King's College Hospital criteria can be used to assess the prognosis.

MELD (Model for End-stage Liver Disease) score is used to prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation. However, there are certain diseases that impair patient survival and are not accounted for in the MELD score. Patients with these diseases are given upgraded MELD points to accurately represent the mortality risk and these conditions are called MELD exceptions. 

The MELD exceptions include:-

  • Portopulmonary hypertension
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Familial amyloid polyneuropathy
  • Primary hyperoxaluria (necessitating liver-kidney transplantation)
  • Cystic fibrosis with liver disease
  • Highly selected cases of hilar cholangiocarcinoma.
  • Hepatopulmonary syndrome
  • Hepatic artery thrombosis 7–14 days post-liver transplantation.

Option A: Pitt score is used used to predict mortality in patients having bloodstream infections.

Option B: The child-Pugh score is used to assess the severity of cirrhosis. 

Option D: Maddrey's Discriminant Function (MDF) score suggests which patients with alcoholic hepatitis may have a poor prognosis and benefit from steroid administration.

Related Pearl: Revised Model for End-stage liver disease (MELD) scoring system: MELD 3.0

MELD 3.0 score has the following components (Mnemonic F BASIC)

  • Female sex
  • Bilirubin
  • Albumin
  • Serum sodium (mEq/L)
  • INR (International Normalized ratio)
  • Creatinine

Uses:

  • Predict short-term prognosis in patients undergoing transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) insertion
  • Assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation
  • Assess prognosis in cirrhosis

questions.text: A child presents with hepatitis and progressive neurological degeneration. A picture of his eye has been provided below. Which among the following investigation would help in this child's diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring seen in the image suggest Wilson's disease. The initial step regarding investigations done for the diagnosis is the measurement of serum ceruloplasmin levels.

The gold standard for diagnosis is a liver biopsy with quantitative copper assays. Other investigations that are used for diagnosis are reduced serum ceruloplasmin, elevated urine copper, elevated liver copper, elevated aminotransferases, and positive ATP7B mutation. The role of total serum copper in the diagnosis of Wilson's disease is limited. Measurement of serum ceruloplasmin and urinary copper is preferred.

Lab investigations in Wilson's disease would show:

Lab markers Change in Wilson's disease Reason
Serum ceruloplasmin ↓↓↓ ATP7B deficiency results in reduced bound copper
24h urinary copper ↑↑ Excess free copper excreted in urine
Total serum copper ↓ Due to marked reduction in ceruloplasmin

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency following an episode of syncope during his morning walk. His blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg. He has a history of myocardial infarction 5 yrs back. His present ECG is given below. Which is the most appropriate treatment for the patient?
questions.solution: The ECG shows wide QRS complex tachycardia with no p waves suggesting the diagnosis of ventricular tachycardia (VT). Clinical features of exercise intolerance and the presence of ischemic heart disease also support the diagnosis of VT. Since he is hemodynamically unstable, the next best step is DC cardioversion. For stable patients, amiodarone is given intravenously.

questions.text: Which electrophysiological activity is responsible for the T wave in ECG?
questions.solution:
The T wave in ECG is due to ventricular repolarisation.

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

ECG wave/interval

Physiological correlates

P wave

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex (up to 0.10s)

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

PR interval  (0.12-0.2s) 

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

QT interval  (up to 0.43s)

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval (Average 0.32s)

(QT minus QRS)

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential+ Ventricular repolarisation

ST segment

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential

questions.text: Which of the following is false with respect to lifestyle modifications for managing essential hypertension as recommended by AHA 2019 guidelines?
questions.solution:
Low potassium increases blood pressure and hence is not recommended in the dietary modifications. On the contrary, potassium supplementation lowers the BP significantly in hypertensives. It is given preferably by dietary modifications unless contraindicated.

Related Pearl: American Heart Association (AHA) 2019 guidelines for hypertension management

According to the AHA hypertension guidelines, 2019, pharmacologic treatment for hypertension is recommended

  • In patients who have ≥10% estimated 10year ASCVD risk, when BP ≥ 130/80 mmHg 
  • In patients who have <10% estimated 10year ASCVD risk when BP ≥ 140/90 mmHg 

 ASCVD - Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease

ASCVD risk is calculated using a calculator provided by the American Heart Association.

 

Lifestyle modifications in the management of hypertension

Intervention Goal Impact on BP
1. Weight reduction The best goal is ideal body weight -5 mmHg
2. Dietary sodium restriction
  • Total sodium - <1.5g/day (AHA 2019 guidelines)
  • Total NaCl (salt) intake - <6g/day
 -5/6 mmHg
3. Enhanced potassium intake 3.5 - 5g/day -4/5 mmHg
4. DASH dietary pattern  high in vegetables, fruits, low-fat dairy products, whole grains, poultry, fish, and nuts and low in sweets, sugar-sweetened beverages, red meats, and saturated and total fat. -11 mmHg
5. Physical activity Aerobic exercise, dynamic resistance and isometric resistance -4-8 mmHg
6. Moderation in alcohol consumption In individuals who drink alcohol - ≤ 2 drinks/ day for men and ≤ 1 drink/ day for women -4 mmHg

DASH – Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension

 

Target BP in hypertensives:

Clinical condition BP Goal, mm Hg
Clinical CVD or 10 year ASCVD risk  > 10% <130/80
No clinical CVD and 10 year ASCVD risk < 10% <130/80
Adults with CKD <130/80
Adults with Type 2 DM  <130/80

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a known history of DM and HTN on regular medications presents with a history of progressively worsening dyspnoea on exertion. On examination, there is elevated JVP, positive hepatojugular reflux, crackles at the lung bases, hepatomegaly, ascites, and pedal oedema​. What is your provisional diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of heart failure.

Heart failure is a complex clinical syndrome that occurs because the ventricle is unable to fill with or eject blood. The etiology of heart failure includes:

  • Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Coronary artery disease
  • Cardiomyopathies
  • Chronic kidney disease
  • High output states, such as beriberi, thyrotoxicosis, severe anemia

Signs and symptoms of heart failure are:

Right heart failure Left heart failure
Due to congestion in the systemic circulation Due to congestion in the lungs. 

Symptoms and signs:

  • Raised JVP
  • Congestive hepatomegaly
  • Positive hepatojugular reflux
  • Ascites
  • Bilateral pitting edema 
  • Weight gain- due to edema
  • Fatigue- due to ↓pumping of blood to lungs leading to ↓oxygenation of the blood

Symptoms and signs: 

  • Dyspnea on exertion
  • Orthopnea
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (characteristic of LVF)
  • Pulmonary rales 
  • Increased PCWP
  • Fatigue- due to ↓cardiac output

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman complains of bluish discoloration of her fingertips on exposure to cold. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Raynaud’s phenomenon. Clonidine is avoided in Raynaud’s phenomenon as it worsens the condition.

Clonidine acts on central alpha-2 adrenoreceptor in CNS and reduces sympathetic outflow. This causes decreased blood pressure and perfusion that can exacerbate Raynaud's phenomenon or any PVD.

Drugs that can be used for the treatment of Raynaud’s phenomenon:

Primary Raynaud's:

  • Dihydropyridine CCBs- nifedipine, isradipine, felodipine, and amlodipine
  • Diltiazem
  • Prazosin, doxazosin, and terazosin

Secondary Raynaud's:

  • Phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors- sildenafil and tadalafil

Digital sympathectomy is helpful in some patients who are unresponsive to medical therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about upper motor neuron lesions?

choices.text: Proximal muscle groups are affected more than the distal muscle groups

questions.solution:
Extensor plantar reflex (positive Babinski's sign) is seen in upper motor neuron lesions. 

Other options:

  • The distal muscle groups are affected more than the proximal muscles and the axial muscles are spared (as the anterior corticospinal tracts supplying the axial muscles have bilateral representation). Axial muscles are involved when the lesion is severe or bilateral.
  • Hypertonia in the form of spasticity is seen in the upper motor neuron lesions, while fasciculations and hypotonia are features of lower motor neuron lesions.

Related Pearl: Features of Motor Neuron Lesions

Upper Motor Neuron Lesion

Lower Motor Neuron Lesion

Upper motor neuron typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons, but they can also include brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons

Lower motor neurons are those whose axons terminate on skeletal muscles

Little or no muscle wasting . UMN lesions result in weakness of relatively large group of muscles

Muscle atrophy → muscle weakness of an individual and specific muscle

Hypertonia

Hypotonia

Increased or exaggerated deep tendon reflexes (hyperreflexia)

Hyporeflexia or areflexia

Spasticity

Flaccidity

Positive Babinski sign (abnormal plantar extensor reflex)

Fasciculations

questions.text: Mr.Murali, a 60-year-old patient with atrial fibrillation complains of sudden onset weakness of the right lower limb, urinary incontinence, and fecal incontinence. MRI shows an ischemic stroke involving the left anterior cerebral artery. Which of the following features are not seen in this type of stroke?
questions.solution:
Aphasia is not seen in anterior cerebral artery occlusion. They are seen in occlusion of the middle cerebral artery.

Anterior cerebral artery (ACA) supplies parts of the frontal lobe, corpus callosum, paracentral lobule, and other deeper structures.

Signs and symptoms of ACA occlusion and structures involved:

  • Urinary incontinence, fecal incontinence
  • Paratonic rigidity
  • Abulia (Akinetic mutism), lack of spontaneity, slowness
  • Gait impairment
  • Paralysis of contralateral foot and leg
  • Paresis of the contralateral arm
  • Cortical sensory loss over contralateral lower limb
  • Dyspraxia of left limbs, tactile aphasia in left limbs

questions.text: Ipsilateral abducens nerve weakness and facial nerve palsy with contralateral hemiplegia is seen in _______
questions.solution:
Ipsilateral abducens and facial nerve palsy with contralateral hemiplegia are seen in Millard–Gubler syndrome.

CNS lesion  

  Effects

Millard–Gubler Syndrome

Ipsilateral abducens nerve weakness

Ipsilateral facial nerve palsy

Contralateral hemiplegia

Raymond’s Syndrome

Ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy

Contralateral hemiplegia

Foville’s Syndrome

 

Lateral gaze palsy

Ipsilateral facial nerve palsy

Contralateral hemiplegia

Balint's syndrome

Optic ataxia

Ocular apraxia

Visuospatial disorientation

   In Millard-Gubler syndrome there is a ventral pontine injury (lesion in abducens fascicle) that causes lateral rectus palsy.  In Foville's syndrome, there is a dorsal pontine injury (lesion in the abducens nucleus) that causes lateral gaze palsy.

questions.text: What is the GCS of a patient with a head injury who opens her eyes in response to a loud voice, localizes pain, and is confused and disoriented?
questions.solution:
In this patient GCS is E3M5V4

Eye-opening to loud voice-3

Motor response localizes pain-5

 Verbal response is confused and disoriented-4

GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.

questions.text: A 21 year old female complains of fever, headache and vomiting from the past 3 days. She has been living in the army recruitment camp for the last three weeks. On examination she has neck stiffness and flexion of the neck causes flexion of the hips and knees. A maculopapular rash can be found over the trunk and extremities and she is hypotensive. Which of the following is false about this disease?

choices.text: Carriers can be treated with Rifampicin
It is caused by a catalase positive and oxidase positive organism
Terminal complement deficiency increases the risk of this disease
Metronidazole is the drug of choice for this disease

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of meningococcal meningitis. Metronidazole is not the drug of choice for this disease. Meningococcal meningitis is treated with cephalosporins.

Meningococcal meningitis is caused by Neisseria meningitides, a gram-negative, oxidase-positive, catalase-positive diplococci. The risk of infection is increased in patients with terminal complement deficiency, hypogammaglobulinemia and hyposplenism as opsonization by complement is a major mechanism by which the bacteria is cleared from the blood.

Characteristic clinical findings include :

  • Maculopapular or purpuric rash
  • Shock due to capillary leak
  • Adrenal hemorrhage

Cephalosporins are the drug of choice for meningococcal meningitis. Rifampicin, ciprofloxacin and cephalosporins are used to treat carriers.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with recurrent paranasal sinus pain and occasional hemoptysis. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated ESR and red cell casts in the urine. Serology is positive for cANCA. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis). The patient shows the involvement of the upper respiratory tract (sinusitis), lower respiratory tract (occasional hemoptysis), renal system (red cell casts), and the presence of cANCA antibodies.

It is a granulomatous, necrotizing vasculitis of the small vessels which mainly affects

  • Upper respiratory tract- presenting with sinusitis, otitis media, and nasal septal perforation
  • Lower respiratory tract- presenting with hemoptysis
  • Renals (glomerulonephritis)- presenting with proteinuria, hematuria, and hypertension.

Apart from these organs, the disease can also affect the eye and skin. Skin lesions present as palpable purpura or subcutaneous nodules. Laboratory investigations show anemia, leucocytosis, elevated ESR, and cANCA positivity.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of sarcoidosis presents with skin lesions shown in the image below. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The given condition is lupus pernio.

Lupus pernio is a cutaneous manifestation of sarcoidosis. It involves the bridge of the nose, the area beneath the eyes, and the cheeks.

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous inflammatory condition with multisystem involvement. The most common organs affected are the lungs, liver, eye, and skin. The most widely accepted etiological hypothesis is an inflammatory response to an infectious or non-infectious trigger in a susceptible host.

There are two syndromes that are associated with the condition.

  • Lofgren's syndrome is characterized by erythema nodosum and hilar adenopathy. Periarticular arthritis can also be seen.
  • Mikulicz syndrome is bilateral involvement of parotid, submaxillary, and sublingual glands. 

The most common presenting features are cough, dyspnea, fever, night sweats, and weight loss.  The eyes can be involved in the form of anterior uveitis, photophobia, dry eyes, and blurred vision. Neurological involvement in the form of myelopathy, basilar meningitis, and facial nerve paralysis. Skin involvement can be seen as maculopapular lesions, keloid formation, ad subcutaneous nodules. Lupus pernio refers to the skin involvement of the bridge of the nose, periocular region, and cheeks and points to a chronic state.

Histopathological examination reveals non-necrotizing granulomas made of macrophages and giant cells. Calcium and protein concretions known as Schaumann bodies and stellate inclusions called asteroid bodies may be seen within the giant cells. 

Chest X-ray is preferred to stage lung involvement. CT features include peribronchial thickening and reticular nodular changes.

Glucocorticoids are the drug of choice for management.

Other options:

Option A- Lupus vulgaris is a manifestation of cutaneous tuberculosis.

Option C- Heliotrope rash presents as violaceous lesions around eyelids. It is seen in dermatomyositis.

Option D- Erysipelas presents as erythematous raised lesions with sharply demarcated edges. It is caused due to streptococcal skin infection.

questions.text: You suspect rheumatoid arthritis in a patient presenting with pain in her hands and having swelling and tenderness in proximal interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints. What is the most specific marker for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The most specific marker for rheumatoid arthritis is anti-CCP antibody (cyclic citrullinated peptide).

Anti-CCP, ESR, and CRP values correlate with the disease activity.

Rheumatoid factor can occur in other autoimmune diseases as well and in chronic infections. Therefore it is not specific.

questions.text: Modified Schober’s test is performed in?
questions.solution:
Modified Schober’s test is performed in ankylosing spondylitis to detect reduced flexion of the spine.

The test involves marking two points- 10 cm above and 5cm below the level of the lumbosacral junction of the patient. The patient is then asked to bend forward and the distance between the two points is measured.

This distance normally increases by ≥5 cm. An increase of <4 cm indicates reduced flexion.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male who is a lifetime non-smoker is likely to develop which type of lung cancer?
questions.solution:
The most common lung cancer in lifetime non-smokers, light smokers (<10 pack-year history), women, and younger adults (<60 years) is adenocarcinoma. In smokers, the most common types are small-cell lung cancers and squamous cell carcinomas.

WHO classification of lung carcinomas:

The WHO classification system divides epithelial lung cancers into four major cell types:

  • Small-cell lung cancer (SCLC)
  • Non-small-cell lung carcinomas (NSCLCs)
    • Adenocarcinoma
    • Squamous cell carcinoma
    • Large-cell carcinoma

SCLC may be distinguished from NSCLC by the presence of neuroendocrine markers including CD56, neural cell adhesion molecule (NCAM), synaptophysin, and chromogranin.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents to the OPD with mild fever since 12 days, non-productive cough, headache, and neck rigidity. The patient also complained of multiple joint pains. A chest x-ray was done which shows interstitial infiltration. Which is the most likely causative organism for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of mild fever, insidious onset and non-productive cough along with extrapulmonary manifestations i.e neck rigidity(aseptic meningitis) and joint pains are highly suggestive of mycoplasma (Walking Pneumonia). On chest X-ray interstitial infiltration along with patchy consolidation at hilum and fanning to the periphery is seen (as shown above)

Mycoplasma is the most common bacteria causing atypical pneumonia and the second most common cause of pneumonia. Clinically it has an insidious onset, non-productive cough, and milder fever compared to typical pneumonia.   Only 10% of patients present with pneumonia. URTI (tracheobronchitis/ pharyngitis) is a common pulmonary manifestation.

It is often associated with extrapulmonary manifestations. Extrapulmonary manifestations include neurologic manifestations like encephalitis or aseptic meningitis (as seen in this patient), cold agglutinin disease (IgM mediated AIHA), Erythema multiforme or SJS, arthralgia with adenopathy, Guillain barre syndrome, myocarditis, pericarditis, encephalitis, and bullous myringitis.  Investigations include PCR of respiratory secretions and chest X-rays.

Azithromycin is the drug of choice for management. Doxycycline is the second-best drug for the management of atypical pneumonia.

questions.text: Infertility in Klinefelter's syndrome is due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Infertility in Klinefelter’s syndrome is due to azoospermia i.e. a complete absence of sperm in the semen.

Klinefelter's syndrome is a genetic disorder that results from a 47, XXY karyotype. These patients are phenotypically male and present with infertility due to hyalinization of the seminiferous tubules and no spermatogenesis. Hence, the present with testes of small volume. They have manifestations of androgen deficiency such as average stature, sparse body hair, low libido, etc. Relatively elevated estradiol levels result in gynecomastia. Other features include possible thromboses, varicose veins, osteoporosis, etc. These patients are advised to undergo frequent mammography screening due to the increased breast cancer risk.

The most important treatment measure is with supplementation of testosterone. Dosage is decided on an individualized basis depending on the patient's current levels. 

Fertility can be achieved using the artificial reproductive technique of intracytoplasmic sperm injection from the patient into the egg of the partner. 

Other options-

Option (A): Asthenospermia is the cause of infertility in Kartagener’s syndrome, also known as primary ciliary dyskinesia. It presents with the classical triad of situs inversus, bronchiectasis, and chronic sinusitis. Asthenospermia is the decreased motility of spermatozoa due to abnormal ciliary motility seen in this syndrome. It occurs due to defects in the dynein arm of cilia. Ciliary motility is not affected in Klinefelter's syndrome.

Option (C): Undescended testes are not seen in patients with Klinefelter's syndrome.

Option (D): Epididymis obstruction can cause infertility due to sexually transmitted infections and congenital malformations. The most common organisms responsible for the infective etiology are C. trachomatis and N. gonorrheae. Coliform organisms can also be causative in men who have sex with men. This is not the cause of infertility in Klinefelter's syndrome.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with persistent fever and productive cough for 6 weeks with night sweats and anemia. The following is his CXR. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described along with the chest X-ray image showing air-fluid level is suggestive of a lung abscess.

The patients usually present with complaints of fever, cough with sputum production, and chest pain. Patients with putrid lung abscesses may report foul-smelling sputum. Patients with chronic lung abscesses usually have a history of night sweats, fatigue, and anemia.

On physical examination:

  • Poor dentition/gingival disease
  • Amphoric and/or cavernous breath sounds on lung auscultation
  • Digital clubbing
  • The absence of a gag reflex

CXR features of lung abscess:

  • A lung cavity with an air-fluid level
  • The cavity wall is thick and irregular, and a surrounding pulmonary-infiltrate is often present
  • Computed tomography (CT) is more sensitive than chest radiography and is used to detect small cavities

The two x-ray images given below show thick-walled cavities with air-fluid levels on lateral and PA views respectively.

Other options:

Carcinoma Lung:

  • Carcinoma of the lung can also present with symptoms like persistent cough, fever, night sweats, and anemia, especially if it has advanced and caused complications like infection or bleeding.
  • However, the CXR would show a different pattern such as a solitary pulmonary nodule, mass lesion, or hilar enlargement.
  • It may also demonstrate signs of metastasis such as multiple nodules in the lungs or distant spread to other organs, which are not apparent in the provided CXR.

Emphysematous bullae:

  • Emphysematous bullae are large air spaces within the lung parenchyma that can occur due to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or other lung conditions.
  • While emphysema can lead to symptoms like cough and occasionally fever if there's a concurrent infection, it typically does not present with prolonged fever, night sweats, and anemia as prominent features. Additionally, the CXR shows consolidation rather than bullae.

Tuberculosis (TB):

  • TB is less likely in this scenario due to the presence of clinical features such as foul-smelling sputum, digital clubbing, and the absence of a gag reflex, which are not typical of TB.
  • Additionally, the CXR findings of a thick-walled cavity with an air-fluid level are more suggestive of a lung abscess.

questions.text: A daily-wage worker from the cement industry got a chest X-ray as a part of his routine health check-up. What could be the cause of the findings shown below?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows irregular opacities, which appear to be pleural thickenings i.e., pleural plaques. The sign along with a history of working in the cement industry suggests a diagnosis of asbestosis.

Workers of the cement, shipping, and textile industries are at a higher risk of developing asbestosis. Asbestos tends to involve the pleura first. 

The earliest manifestation is benign asbestosis-related pleural effusion. With time, the plaques calcify resulting in the formation of thick pleural plaques. The pleural thickenings can be seen on the X-ray. This is the “holly leaf sign”.

Lung parenchymal involvement occurs after years of exposure (at least 10 years). They present with cough and exertional dyspnoea. It predominantly affects the lower lobes of the lung, in contrast to other forms of pneumoconiosis, which affect the upper lobes.

Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis typically shows a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.

The image below shows thick plueral plaques.

questions.text:
Calculate the anion gap from the following values:
Na+ = 137 mmol/L
K+ = 4 mmol/L
Cl- = 100 mmol/L
HCO3- = 15 mmol/L
questions.solution:
The anion gap is 22 mmol/L.

The “anion gap” (which is only a diagnostic concept) is the difference between measured cations and measured anions and is estimated as:

Plasma anion gap = [Na+ ] − [HCO3− ] − [Cl− ]

Substituting the values = 137−15−100 = 22 mmol/L

The normal anion gap ranges between 8-16 mmol/L.

The concentrations of anions and cations in plasma must be equal to maintain electrical neutrality. Therefore, there is no real “anion gap” in the plasma. 

However, only certain cations and anions are routinely measured in the clinical laboratory. The cation normally measured is Na+, and the anions are usually Cl− and HCO3−.

Usually, the unmeasured anions exceed the unmeasured cations.

The anion gap will increase if unmeasured anions rise or if unmeasured cations fall:

  • Unmeasured cations - calcium, magnesium, and potassium
  • Unmeasured anions - albumin, phosphate, sulfate, and other organic anions

Decreased anion gap (<6 mEq/L) is seen in:

  • Increase in unmeasured cations
  • An addition of abnormal cations to the blood, such as:
    • Lithium (lithium intoxication)
    • Cationic immunoglobulins (plasma cell dyscrasias)
  • Reduction in the plasma anion albumin concentration (nephrotic syndrome, liver disease, or malabsorption)
  • Hyperviscosity and severe hyperlipidemia, can lead to an underestimation of sodium and chloride concentrations.

questions.text: The arterial blood gas findings of a patient are pH = 7.12, pCO2 = 50, HCO3 = 28. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above findings give the diagnosis of respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: pH is reduced (7.12), hence acidosis.

Step 2: Since pCO2 is raised (50 mmHg), it is respiratory acidosis.

Step 3: HCO3 is raised (28 mEq/L) suggesting there is metabolic compensation.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: An alcohol addict presented with easy fatiguability. On examination, he is found to have pallor. Peripheral smear showed macrocytes and anisocytosis. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of megaloblastic anemia likely due to folate deficiency caused by alcohol addiction.

Megaloblastic anaemia may be caused by vitamin B12 deficiency or folic acid deficiency. Cyanocobalamin (vitamin B12) and folic acid are co-factors required for DNA synthesis. Thus, in B12 deficiency there is impairment of DNA synthesis that leads to defective nuclear maturation, ineffective hematopoiesis, and distinctive morphologic changes. These include abnormally large erythroid precursors and red cells. 

Peripheral smears in megaloblastic anemia show hypersegmented neutrophils, with five or more nuclear lobules instead of the normal three to four.

Folate deficiency leads to atrophic glossitis because of damage to the epithelial surfaces as shown in the image below.

Other options:

Option B: Migratory glossitis/geographic tongue is due to rapid loss and regrowth of filiform papillae of the tongue. It is a benign inflammatory condition of the tongue associated with psoriasis and reactive arthritis.

The image below shows migratory glossitis.

Option C: Strawberry tongue is due to the hypertrophy of fungiform papillae. It is seen in scarlet fever and Kawasaki disease.

The image below shows the strawberry tongue.

Option D: Macroglossia is an abnormal enlargement of the tongue and can be congenital or acquired. New-onset macroglossia in adults is highly suggestive of amyloidosis.

The image below shows macroglossia.

questions.text: A clinical trial is evaluating the specificity of nuclear-based scanning protocol in diagnosing primary Hyperparathyroidism. During the course of their study, they find that some individuals who tested positive with the scan showed no other evidence of Hyperparathyroidism and were instead found to be suffering from a Hurthle Cell Nodule of the Thyroid Gland. Which of the following radioactive tracer tests could be used to rule out the false positives?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, a thyroid-specific tracer like 99Tc- Pertechnetate could be used to rule out the false positives caused by the solid thyroid nodules. 

The Sestamibi scanning is a nuclear-based imaging test used to localize the Parathyroid glands. Sestamibi accumulates in the Mitochondria and therefore washes out at differential rates depending on the number of mitochondria in individual tissue. Parathyroid adenomas often have a high concentration of oxyphilic cells with high mitochondrial content, hence retain tracers and therefore have a slow washout compared to the thyroid gland. The false positives that might arise because of the highly oxyphilic lesion like Hürthle cell nodules can be reduced by the addition of thyroid-specific radioactive tracer 99Tc-pertechnetate and subsequent subtraction images.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male undergoes bilateral adrenalectomy for phaeochromocytoma. On the third postoperative day, the boy feels lethargic and tired. Blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg, there is no sign of bleed. What could be the cause of this?
questions.solution:
The clinical features given in the question are suggestive of Addisonian crisis.

Addisonian crisis is a life-threatening condition caused due to sudden insufficiency of adrenal hormones. Normally, adrenal corticosteroids help to retain sodium and maintain normal intravascular volume. Sudden lack of these hormones causes excessive loss of sodium, decreased intravascular volume, low blood pressure and eventually circulatory collapse.

The causes are either primary or secondary. Primary causes include adrenal haemorrhage, acute infection, etc, while the secondary causes include surgery, cessation of steroid therapy, postpartum pituitary necrosis, etc.

Treatment includes fluid and glucocorticoid replacement.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female patient with a history of breast and ovarian cancers in her siblings underwent genetic testing. She is found to have a mutation in the BRCA1 gene.  She is at the risk of developing:
questions.solution:
Individuals with BRCA1 mutations are likely to develop triple receptor-negative and high-grade breast carcinomas.

Related Pearl: Comparison between BRCA 1 and BRCA 2:

Both BRCA1 and BRCA2 are tumor suppressor genes.

Carcinoma breast occurs at an earlier age and is bilateral and multicentric in inherited forms compared to sporadic cases.

  BRCA 1 BRCA 2
Location Long arm of chromosome 17  Long arm of chromosome 13
Differentiation Poorly differentiated Well-differentiated
Hormone receptor status ER/PR- Negative, Her-2 negative – triple negative ER/PR- Positive
Associated Cancers Breast, ovarian, colon, and prostate (lesser extent), Pancreas (lesser extent)  cancers Breast, ovarian, colon, prostate, pancreas, gall bladder, stomach cancers, and melanoma
Male breast carcinoma  Low association Increased risk
Fanconi’s anemia  Associated Associated
Medullary carcinoma Associated No association

 

Related Pearl: Breast Cancer Screening

Breast Cancer Screening*

Individuals are encouraged to conduct a risk assessment by 25 years of age. This helps classify them into average risk or increased risk groups.

Recommendations: 

  1. Average-risk (no known genetic or family history of breast cancer)
    • 25-39 years of age: clinical breast examination every 1-3 years; 
    • ≥ 40 years of age: clinical breast examination and mammogram annually
  2. Increased risk (positive family or genetic history of breast cancer)
    • Consult a healthcare professional every 6-12 months after 21 years of age
    • Annual mammogram or MRI from 25 years of age or 10 years prior to the age at which the youngest family member was diagnosed with breast cancer (whichever is earliest)
  3. Asymptomatic women with previously treated breast cancer
    • Consult a healthcare professional every 6-12 months
    • Annual mammogram
    • Annual MRI to be considered
  4. Mammogram and USG are not contraindicated in pregnant and breastfeeding women

High-risk patients for breast cancer:

  1. Women (or a first-degree relative) with a known BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation or TP53 or PTEN genes
  2. Two first-degree relatives with breast cancers with or without gene mutations
  3. Women with a history of chest irradiation between the ages of 10 and 30
  4. Women with previously biopsy-proven breast cancer
  5. Women with ≥ 20% lifetime risk for breast cancer based on breast cancer risk models

*According to NCCN 2022 guidelines

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors (50% to 65% of tumors) – range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

questions.text: Which one of the following is incorrect regarding acute arterial occlusion?

choices.text: Pain, pallor, paralysis, pulselessness, parasthesia/anesthesia are characteristic
Ischemia beyond 6 hrs is usually irreversible
Limb will be warm and toes cannot be moved
Embolectomy and Thrombolysis are the treatment

questions.solution:
The limb is cold and the toes cannot be moved, which contrasts with venous occlusion when muscle function is not affected. The diagnosis can be made clinically in a patient who has no history of claudication and has a source of emboli, who suddenly develops severe pain or numbness of the limb, which becomes cold and mottled. 

Embolic arterial occlusion is an emergency that requires immediate treatment. Ischaemia beyond 6 hours is usually irreversible and results in limb loss.

The leg is often affected, with pain, pallor, paralysis, loss of pulsation and paraesthesia (or anesthesia)

questions.text: Paraneoplastic syndrome is usually associated with which type of lung cancer?
questions.solution:
• Paraneoplastic Syndrome is usually associated with small cell carcinoma.
  • Squamous Cell Carcinoma is associated with Smoking and Central necrosis.
  • Adenocarcinoma Metastasize earlier and is more common in women, it is the most common type of Carcinoma lung worldwide.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male on evaluation for intermittent dysphagia shows the following characteristic appearance on barium swallow. The probable diagnosis is______.
questions.solution:
The barium swallow shows a thin circumferential ring in the distal esophagus, which is suggestive of Schatzki’s ring.

Schatzki’s ring:

  • Schatzki’s ring is a circular ring in the distal esophagus (squamocolumnar junction) associated with gastroesophageal reflux disorder (GERD).
  • Concentric, nonmalignant, fibrous thickening and narrowing of the gastroesophageal junction (GEJ), with squamous epithelium above and columnar cells below.
  • The core of the ring consists of variable amounts of fibrous tissue and cellular infiltrate.
  • The cause is unknown, and correlations to reflux disease and hiatal hernia are still debatable. 
  • It may cause dysphagia.
  • Treatment is endoscopic dilation with antireflux therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Obesity Surgery-Mortality Risk Score (OS-MRS)?
questions.solution:
Type-2 Diabetes mellitus (DM) is not a component of the Obesity Surgery-Mortality Risk Score (OS-MRS).

Edmonton Obesity Staging System (EOSS) and Obesity Surgery-Mortality Risk Score (OS-MRS) are used to discuss with patients the likely prognosis without surgery, and the risk of complications.

Obesity Surgery-Mortality Risk Score (OS-MRS):

Risk factor Score
Age ≥ 45 yr 1
BMI ≥ 50 1
Male gender 1
Hypertension 1
DVT(Deep Vein Thrombosis)/ PE(Pulmonary Embolism) 1
Risk Category Score Post-op mortality
A (Low) 0-1 0.3
B (Moderate) 2-3 1.7
C (High) 4-5 3.2

Note:

Uncontrolled diabetes is considered a risk factor, as is in any other surgery. However, it is not considered under the OS-MRS scoring system.

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a risk factor for an anastomotic leak. Treatment with continuous positive airway pressure might reduce this risk.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with Reynold's pentad?
questions.solution:
Vomiting is not associated with Reynold’s pentad.

Reynold's pentad is seen in severe cholangitis. It includes the following clinical symptoms:

  • Charcot's triad
    • Fever
    • Right upper quadrant pain
    • Jaundice
  • Hypotension
  • Altered mental status

Related Pearl: Charcot and Reynold's Triad

Charcot's triad - in acute cholangitis

  • Right upper quadrant pain
  • Fever with chills
  • Jaundice

Reynold's pentad - in acute suppurative cholangitis

  • Charcot’s triad + Altered mental status + Hypotension

questions.text: The most common indication for splenectomy is _____
questions.solution:
Overall, the most common indication for splenectomy is trauma to the spleen, whether external (blunt or penetrating) or iatrogenic (e.g., during operative procedures for other reasons).

Note: The Most common indication for:

  • Elective splenectomy: Haematological disorders such as ITP, TTP, etc.
  • Emergency splenectomy: Trauma
  • Splenectomy (overall): Trauma

 

Related Pearl: Indications for splenectomy

Trauma (most common)

  • Accidental
  • Operative

Oncological

  • Part of en bloc resection
  • Diagnostic
  • Therapeutic

Haematological

  • Spherocytosis
  • Purpura (idiopathic/immune thrombocytopenic purpura)
  • Hypersplenism

Portal hypertension

  • Variceal surgery

questions.text: A man presents with a history of cloudy urine immediately after reaching sexual climax. He is a known diabetic and underwent TURP 6 months ago. Which of the following is the mechanism leading to the development of this complication?

choices.text: Injury to the external urethral sphincter
Disruption of the autonomic nerve supply to the corpora of the penis
Over use of coagulating diathermy during the procedure

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario above suggests the patient has retrograde ejaculation. The most likely mechanism of its development is disruption of the bladder neck. 

Retrograde ejaculation is the most common complication of transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP). 

Other complications of TURP include the following: 

  • Perforation of the bladder
  • Sepsis
  • Incontinence
  • Urethral stricture
  • TURP syndrome/water intoxication: Absorption of water into the circulation at the time of TURP can give rise to congestive cardiac failure, hyponatremia, and hemolysis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the following image?

choices.text: Alcoholism predisposes to the development of this condition.
A mixed infection with aerobic and anaerobic bacteria is most common.

questions.solution:
The image above indicates that the patient has Fournier's gangrene, and despite best therapy, mortality rates are 50%. 

Concurrent illnesses like diabetes mellitus and alcoholism, predispose patients to Fournier's gangrene. 

The sequence of events are as follows: A mixed infection of the aerobic and anaerobic bacteria → fulminating inflammation of subcutaneous tissue → obliterative arteritis of the arterioles that supply the scrotal skin → gangrene

The testis is usually not affected.

It is a surgical emergency.

questions.text: Identify the type of flap.
questions.solution:
The picture shows a radial forearm free flap. In a free flap the blood supply is isolated, disconnected and then reconnected using micosurgery at the new site. Other eg: DIEP (Deep inferior epigastric perforators) flap, free fibular flap

  • A random flap include three sides of a rectangle, bearing no specific relationship to where the blood supply enters.Eg:V-Y plasty, Z plasty, Limberg or rhomboid flap.
  • Axial flap is much longer and is based on known blood vessels. Eg: Latissmus dorsi flap,TRAM (Transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous) flap
  • Islanded flap are those in which the axial blood supply is swung round on a stalk.

Note:

Flap defines the tongue of tissue; pedicle is used to describe the base or stem with the vascular supply.

Skin-bearing flaps are classified according to three basic characteristics—

  • Composition: refers to the tissue contained within the flap, such as cutaneous, musculocutaneous, fasciocutaneous etc
  • Method of movement:
    • Local transfer, eg. advancement or rotation flaps
    • Distant transfer, eg. pedicle flaps from the abdomen to the perineum or micro-vascular free flaps.
  • Blood supply
    • Musculocutaneous arteries travel perpendicularly through muscle to the overlying skin.
    • Septocutaneous arteries travel with intermuscular fascial septa to supply the overlying skin.

questions.text: A female baby born at 30 weeks of gestation was admitted to NICU for prematurity and respiratory distress. She was placed on CPAP and enteric feeds were started. On day 5 of admission, the baby became lethargic and there was distension of the abdomen. A plain radiograph of the abdomen shows the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows multiple air bubbles within the bowel wall. This is called pneumatosis intestinalis and is pathognomonic of necrotizing enterocolitis.

Necrotizing enterocolitis:

It is the necrosis of bowel and is the most common gastrointestinal surgical emergency in neonates.

The most important risk factor is prematurity. 

It usually occurs in the first few days of life after the initiating enteral feeds. The babies become lethargic and develop abdominal distension, abdominal tenderness, bloody stools, and feeding intolerance.

Milder cases are treated with gut rest, antibiotics, and parenteral nutrition. Severe cases need laparotomy.

questions.text: All these can be done to transport a polytrauma patient who is conscious except?

choices.text: Strap his thorax, abdomen and lower limbs on a stretcher
In prone position to prevent aspiration
Put patient on lateral position and shift him soon
Roll the patient and put on a hard board

questions.solution:
Patients with polytrauma are shifted in supine or prone position (not in lateral position) by laying them over a firm surface, to restrict the spinal movement.

As per ATLS guidelines:

Patient’s with trauma – Airway management is first done along with cervical spine stabilisation. All trauma patients – unless proved otherwise are considered to have an injured vertebral column.

The patients are placed supine on a firm surface without rotating or bending the spinal column and a rigid cervical collar is applied. Aspiration can be prevented by putting the patient in prone position and strapping can be done to provide stabilisation.

Long spine boards with straps are helpful in rapid transport of the patient from one place to other. The patient can be put on the long spine board by logrolling (a technique where, four people hold the patient, and roll the patient like a log, without rotating or bending the spine).

Conscious and alert patient indirectly means that they don’t need intubation and their airway is patent. If the patient is unconscious always verify the airway and if needed, endotracheal intubation must be done immediately by various methods. Preferably by direct laryngoscopy and intubation.

questions.text: The risk of malignancy in “cold” lesions detected on radionuclide thyroid scanning is:
questions.solution:
The risk of malignancy is higher in “cold” lesions (15-20%) as compared to “warm” lesions (<5%).

A thyroid scan is used in patients with hyperthyroidism i.e. low TSH.

A cold nodule indicates reduced function whereas a hot nodule indicates an increased function in that part of the gland. 

Hot nodules are rarely malignant and are further managed with either I131 or surgery.

Cold nodules need to be further evaluated using USG as they pose a higher risk of malignancy.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male tobacco chewer presents to the OPD with a buccal mucosa lesion measuring 7 cm and difficulty in opening the mouth. There is a contralateral cervical lymph node involvement measuring 4 cm, with skin involvement. The TNM staging according to AJCC 8th is ________.
questions.solution:
The TNM staging in this patient is T4bN3bMX.

A 7-cm primary tumor in the oral cavity with difficulty in opening mouth denotes a locally advanced tumor: T4b.

Contralateral cervical lymph node involvement with skin involvement (extranodal extension-positive): N3b

Note:

Here the skin invasion corresponds to ENE positive, and hence, the N staging is N3b instead of N2c (contralateral lymph nodes, <6 cm and ENE‐negative).

Related Pearl: TNM staging of oral cavity cancer - AJCC 8th edition

Primary Tumour (T)
TX Cannot be assessed
Tis Carcinoma in situ
T1

Tumor ≤2 cm, depth of invasion (DOI)  ≤5 mm (DOI is depth of invasion and not tumor thickness)
T2

Tumor ≤2 cm, DOI >5 mm and ≤10 mm;

or tumor >2 cm but ≤4 cm, and ≤10 mm DOI
T3 Tumor >4 cm or any tumor >10 mm DOI
T4 Moderately advanced or very advanced local disease
T4a

Moderately advanced local disease:

Tumor> 4 cms with DOI >10 mm

or tumor invades adjacent structures only (through cortical bone of the mandible or maxilla or involves the maxillary sinus or skin of the face.

Note that superficial erosion of bone/tooth socket (alone) by a gingival primary is not sufficient to classify a tumor as T4
T4b Very advanced local disease; tumor invades the masticator space, pterygoid plates, or skull base and/or encases the internal carotid artery

 

Regional lymph nodes (N) - Clinical
NX Cannot be assessed
N0 No regional lymph node metastasis
N1 Single ipsilateral, <3 cm and ENE (extranodal extension)‐negative
N2  Single ipsilateral lymph node larger than 3 cms but not greater than 6 cms, ENE - negative; Multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, <6 cm and ENE ‐negative ;  Bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, <6 cm and ENE‐negative
N2a Single ipsilateral lymph node larger than 3 cms but not greater than 6 cms, ENE - negative
N2b Multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, <6 cm and ENE ‐negative
N2c Bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, <6 cm and ENE‐negative
N3

Metastasis in a lymph node larger than 6 cms and ENE -negative or metastasis in any lymph node and clinically over ENE +positive
N3a Metastasis in a lymph node >6 cms and ENE‐negative
N3b

Metastasis in any lymph node(s) and clinically overt ENE +positive.


Note:
ENE is as determined by physical examination (e.g., invasion of the skin, infiltration of musculature/dense tethering to adjacent structures, or dysfunction of a cranial nerve, the brachial plexus, the sympathetic trunk, or the phrenic nerve) and supported by radiological evidence, should be present to assign a status of ENE‐positive.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with headache, vomiting, and altered sensorium for the past 6 hours. His wife gives a history of falling in the bathroom and hitting his head 4 weeks ago. On evaluation, the following funduscopic findings are noted. What will be your provisional diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and fundus examination are most probably suggestive of chronic subdural hematoma(SDH). The fundoscopic image shows dilated veins with a blurred disc margin which is suggestive of papilledema.

Chronic SDH is a common cause of acute neurological deterioration in older adults. Due to ageing-related cerebral atrophy, the cortical–dural bridging veins are stretched and vulnerable to rupture. It leads to a haematoma that can expand over days or weeks by osmosis, ultimately producing symptoms of raised ICP or focal deficits. Usually, there is a history of recent head trauma. Antiplatelet or anticoagulant medication can cause SDH with trivial impacts. Patients may present with headaches, seizures, confusion, contralateral hemiparesis, or coma. 

Acute hematomas are bright white (hyperdense) on CT scan for approximately 3 days, after which they fade to isodensity with the brain, and then to hypodensity after 2 to 3 weeks. A chronic SDH will be nearly as dark as CSF on CT.

A chronic SDH >1 cm or any symptomatic SDH should be surgically drained.

Nomenclature

Time

Acute  SDH

<3 days

Subacute SDH

4–21 days

Chronic SDH

> 21 days

 

Related Pearl: Intracranial haemorrhage

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman experiences increased frequency of micturition, pain relieved by micturition, and aggravated by overdistension of the bladder. Urine routine tests showed no pus cells; urine culture tested negative; and cystoscopy revealed fissures and punctate hemorrhages in the bladder mucosa. What is the most probable clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable clinical diagnosis in the reported case is interstitial cystitis.

Interstitial cystitis (i.e., chronic pelvic pain syndrome or bladder pain syndrome) is a persistent, painful form of chronic cystitis, occurring most frequently in women.

Ulcerations of the mucosa occurs in the fundus of the bladder (Hunner's ulcer).

In cystoscopic examination, fissures and punctate hemorrhages (glomerulations) are seen in the bladder mucosa.

questions.text: An anxious mother rushed her 2-year-old child to the casualty when she noticed a red-coloured mass protruding from his anus. The mother gave a history of the child straining while passing stools for the past 2 weeks. There was no abdominal tenderness, and on local examination, a 6 cm mass with circumferential folds and slight edema was noted.  How will you manage this child?
questions.solution:
The given history and examination finding is suggestive of rectal prolapse. In children, the prolapse is usually mucosal and should be treated conservatively.

Rectal prolapse occurs when a mucosal or full-thickness layer of rectal tissue protrudes through the anal orifice. 

Conservative treatment for rectal prolapse in children is to control:

  • Diarrhea
  • Worm infestation
  • Malnutrition

Sclerotherapy can also be used.

questions.text: The Bosniak classification system is used in assessing patients with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The Bosniak classification system is used for assessing patients with renal cysts.

It divides renal cystic masses into five classes based on imaging characteristics seen on CECT. It is helpful in predicting the risks of malignancy and identifying the appropriate choice of clinical follow-up or treatment.

Renal cyst class Risk of malignancy Workup
1 0% Nil
2 0% Nil
2F 5% USG/ CT follow up
3 50%
  • Partial nephrectomy
  • Radiofrequency ablation - in elderly or poor surgical candidates
4 100% Partial or total nephrectomy

questions.text:
All of the following are indications to perform circumcision in children, except:
  1.   Recurrent balanoposthitis 
  2.   Recurrent UTI with abnormal urinary tract 
  3.   Physiological phimosis (<2yrs of age) 
  4.   Tight frenulum 
  5.   On request
questions.solution:
A tight frenulum and physiological phimosis are not indications of circumcision in children. 

Physiological phimosis is seen in children that are less than 2 years of age due to natural adhesions between the glans and inner preputial skin. It rectifies on its own. 

Circumcision is the surgical removal of the foreskin that covers the glans penis.

Indications of circumcision in children: 

  • True phimosis (associated with a white, scarred preputial orifice, most common just before puberty)
  • Paraphimosis
  • On request (most common) 
  • Balanitis xerotica obliterans (BXO)
  • Recurrent UTI with abnormal upper urinary tract
  • Recurrent balanoposthitis

Indications of circumcision in adults: 

  • Recurrent balanitis 
  • Tight frenulum (Splitting of frenulum can occur during sexual activity)
  • Inability to retract the foreskin for intercourse

questions.text: All of the following will be your differential diagnosis in a patient with anterior mediastinal mass except:
questions.solution:
Neurogenic tumors are found in the posterior mediastinum and not in the anterior mediastinum.

They are the most common primary tumors of the posterior mediastinum. Schwannomas and Neurilemomas are the most common neurogenic tumors.

Related Pearl: Locations of the Common Mediastinal Masses

Anterior Mediastinum

Middle Mediastinum

Posterior Mediastinum

Thymoma (most common in anterior mediastinum)

Lymphoma

Germ cell tumors

Thyroid and parathyroid
masses

Bronchogenic Cyst

Aneurysm

Thymic cyst

Parathyroid adenoma

Cysts (MC in middle mediastinum):

  • Pericardial (most common)
  • Bronchogenic
  • Enterogenous
  • Neuroenteric

Vascular masses (an aneurysm)

LN enlargement and lymphoma

Mesenchymal tumors

Pheochromocytoma

Neurogenic tumors 

Meningoceles

Mesenchymal tumors

Pheochromocytoma

Lymphoma

Bronchogenic Cyst

Enterogenous Cyst

questions.text: You are an intern asked to catheterize a patient using a 16F Foley's catheter. You are unable to catheterize the patient and decide to use a slightly smaller catheter. The ward sister gives you the following four fresh catheters. Which one would you choose instead?
questions.solution:
The Foley's catheter having a green coloured ring in the ballon port is of size 14 F. If there is difficulty in catheterization, then a lower French number should be preferred.

Related Pearl: Foley's catheter

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

French scale corresponds to the external circumference in millimetres. French size divided by 3 will give the outer diameter of the catheter. 

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 3 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 3 mm and a diameter of 1 mm. 

Note:

Colour of the foleys is the colour at the baloon port as shown in the figure below

questions.text: A  patient in your ward is to be started on enteral nutrition. All of the following can be used as means of delivery, except:
questions.solution:
A peripherally inserted central venous catheter (PICC) line is used for providing parenteral nutrition.

The term enteral feeding means the delivery of nutrients into the gastrointestinal tract. This can be achieved with oral supplements (sip feeding) or with a variety of tube-feeding techniques such as nasogastric tubes (Ryle’s), fine-bore feeding tubes, surgical or percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG).

questions.text: Most common organ that herniates in Morgagni’s hernia is ______
questions.solution:
The transverse colon is the most common herniating structure in a Morgagni hernia.

Morgagni Hernia:

  • A hernia in the anterior part of the diaphragm with a defect between the sternal and costal attachments
  • The most commonly involved viscus is the transverse colon.

Morgagni hernia:

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is rushed to the emergency department following a high-speed road traffic collision. His heart rate is 124/min, BP is 78/56 mm Hg on the right arm, and 64/50 mm Hg on the left arm. A portable chest X-ray shows a widened mediastinum but normal lung and cardiac silhouette. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of aortic injury. The investigation of choice in this hemodynamically unstable patient is TEE (transesophageal echocardiography). In hemodynamically stable patients the investigation of choice is CECT or CT angiogram.

Traumatic aortic injuries are commonly seen in deceleration injuries (e.g road traffic accidents). The most common site of aortic injury is the isthmus, near the attachment of ligamentum arteriosum. 

Clinical features can be 

  • hypotension
  • difference in blood pressure in bilateral limbs
  • absent pulse in the unilateral limb
  • widened mediastinum on chest X-ray

Management

  • Volume replacement : fluid therapy and blood transfusion
  • Permissive hypotension: Beta-blockers, such as esmolol can be used.
  • Immediate surgical repair:  
    • endovascular stenting, or
    • open surgical repair with Dacron graft.

questions.text: According to the Japanese classification for gastric carcinoma, which of the following is the level 5 lymph node?
questions.solution:
Suprapyloric nodes are the level 5 gastric lymph nodes.

The japanese classification for gastric carcinoma (JCGC) staging system divided lymph nodes into 16 groups based on the likelihood of metastasis from the primary tumor and removal of lymph nodes during gastrectomy.

The surgery for gastric cancer involves the removal of the primary tumor and lymph nodes. Depending on the extent of lymph node stations removed, the surgery may be either  D1 or D2 gastrectomy. 

D1 gastrectomy involves the removal of lymph node stations 1-6. D2 gastrectomy involves the removal of lymph node stations 1-11.

questions.text: A patient presents with polyuria, polydipsia, lethargy and abdominal pain. He had an X-ray taken a few days ago, which is given below. Which of the following investigations would not be useful in arriving at a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the X-ray showing nephrocalcinosis is suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. Angiography of renal arteries is not a useful investigation for hyperparathyroidism.  

Nephrocalcinosis occurs in this condition due to hypercalcemia. It decreases renal concentrating ability, which may cause polyuria and polydipsia.

Clinical features of hyperparathyroidism:

  • Bones:
    • Pathological fractures
    • Subperiosteal bone resorption - 2nd and 3rd digits, most common in radial aspect
    • Salt and pepper skull
    • Osteitis fibrosa cystica or VonReckling Hausen’s disease
  • Stones
    • Multiple and recurrent renal stones - most common
    • Nephrocalcinosis
  • Abdominal groans - colicky due to pancreatitis
  • Psychiatric overtones - raised PTH causing CNS depression and psychiatric symptoms
  • Band keratopathy
  • Features of hypercalcemia - 
    • Vomiting
    • Confusion
    • ECG changes: increased PR interval, shortened QT interval

 The image given below shows salt and pepper skull seen in hyperparathyroidism.

Investigations done in primary hyperparathyroidism:

  • Ultrasonography of the neck is a safe and widely used technique for the localization of abnormal parathyroid glands.  
  • Nuclear medicine scanning with radiolabeled Sestamibi is also a widely used technique. Sestamibi accumulates in parathyroid adenomas. This radionuclide is concentrated in the thyroid and parathyroid tissue but usually washes out of normal thyroid tissue in under an hour. It persists in abnormal parathyroid tissue.  
  • Dual-energy radiographic absorptiometry is a useful tool to demonstrate skeletal involvement in primary hyperparathyroidism.

The image given below shows a radiolabeled Sestamibi scan.

questions.text:
Match the following triads:
Triad Condition
1.Whipple’s Triad a. Hemobilia
2. Sandblom triad b. Gallstone ileus
3. Charcot triad c. Insulinoma
4. Rigler's triad d. Acute cholangitis
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b.

Triad Condition Components
Whipple’s Triad  Insulinoma
  • Symptoms of hypoglycemia
  • Glucose <50 mg/dL
  • Symptomatic relief on glucose ingestion
Sandblom triad Hemobilia
  • Malena
  • Biliary colic
  • Obstructive jaundice
Charcot triad Acute cholangitis
  • Jaundice
  • Fever
  • Right upper quadrant pain
Rigler's triad Gallstone ileus
  • Small bowel obstruction
  • Pneumobilia
  • Ectopic gallstone

Related Pearl: Triads in Surgery

Triad

Seen in
