questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding complications of the Whipple procedure?

choices.text: Delayed gastric emptying is characterized by the need for prolonged nasogastric decompression
Any drainage output on or after postoperative day 3, with amylase >3 times normal value indicates pancreatic fistula
Biliary leakage is the most common complication

questions.solution:
Delayed gastric emptying is the most common complication following the Whipple procedure, not biliary leakage.

Delayed gastric emptying is characterized by the need for prolonged nasogastric decompression or the inability to tolerate oral intake. 

Most pancreatic fistulas are controlled by drainage catheters placed at the time of surgery. A pancreatic leak or pancreatic fistula is defined as the output via an intraoperatively placed drain (or percutaneous drain) of any measurable volume on or after postoperative day 3, with amylase >3 times the normal value. 

Other complications of the Whipple procedure include:

  • Wound infection
  • Intra-abdominal abscess
  • Cardiac events
  • Bile leak
  • Overall reoperation
  • Exocrine insufficiency
  • Endocrine insufficiency

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. Upon arrival, the patient was unconscious with blood pressure of 90/64 mmHg and a pulse rate of 139 per minute. He was immediately transfused with 4 units of packed RBCs. All of the following complications can occur in this patient except:
questions.solution:
The complication of massive transfusion includes hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia.

The lethal triad of massive transfusion includes acidosis, hypothermia, and coagulopathy. Other complications which can be seen in massive transfusion are:

  • Hypocalcaemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia

Related Pearl: Complications of massive transfusion: The concept behind It

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

Complications from massive transfusion include:

  • Hypothermia
  • Alkalosis/Acidosis
  • Coagulopathy
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hyperkalemia

Understanding the concept:

  1. Hypothermia: Blood products are normally stored between 1°C and 6°C, and rapid transfusion of large quantities will lead to hypothermia.
  2. Coagulopathy: MT with PRBCs alone causes a dilutional coagulopathy, whereas massive hemorrhage causes a consumptive coagulopathy. However, the incidence of coagulopathy can be minimized by the infusion of fresh frozen plasma, platelets, and RBCs in a 1:1:1 ratio. 
  3. Alkalosis: As citrate is metabolized to bicarbonate, patients who require MT frequently develop a metabolic alkalosis. 
  4. Acidosis: Due to tissue hypoperfusion
  5. Hyperkalemia & late Hypokalemia: Initially, the patient develops hyperkalemia on massive transfusion. Later, red blood cells begin active metabolism and intracellular potassium uptake. This increased uptake along with metabolic alkalosis (resulting from citrate administration), lowers the serum potassium.
  6. Hypocalcemia: Binding of calcium to citrate (which is used in the anticoagulation of the stored blood).
  7. Hypomagnesemia: Binding of magnesium to citrate

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presented to the OPD with complaints of intermittent constipation and a sense of heaviness in his lower abdomen. His barium enema film is given below. Which of the following statements is false about the pathology responsible for his condition?

choices.text: Commonly occurs along the mesenteric side of the colon
Sigmoid colon is the most common site
It is characterized by true diverticula

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and X-ray film showing saw-toothed appearance of the colon are suggestive of colonic diverticulosis. They are false diverticula.

Diverticulosis refers to the herniation of the mucosa and muscularis mucosa through the colonic wall, usually at the point where the nutrient artery enters the colon (mesenteric side). The condition is usually asymptomatic until complications arise. They may be detected incidentally. On a barium X-ray, the colon with diverticular disease will have a saw-toothed appearance.

Colonic diverticula are more often acquired than congenital. They are common in developed countries that have a low fiber diet. A low fiber diet results in low stool volume. As the colon generates higher intraluminal pressure to propel smaller volumes of stools, low stool volumes cause an increase in colonic wall tension and segmentation of the colon. 

Prolonged colonic contractions and high pressures (directed radially along the colonic wall) results in the formation of pulsion diverticula. The sigmoid colon is the most common site.

Note: True diverticulum involves the herniation of all the layers of the intestine whereas false diverticulum involves the herniation of only the mucosa and submucosa.

questions.text: Which of the following increases the risk of pelvic inflammatory disease?
questions.solution:
Copper IUCDs increase the risk of PID. The most common organism causing PID in an IUCD user is Actinomyces.

OCPs, Mirena and DMPA injectables contain progesterone which causes thickening of the cervical mucus and decreases the motility of the female genital tract. Thus, they reduce the risk of PID by preventing the ascent of bacteria from the vagina.

questions.text: Hormone replacement therapy is not indicated in which of the following patients?
questions.solution:
HRT is no longer recommended for the management of menopausal women with ischemic heart disease.

Indications for HRT is as follows:

  • Severe hot flushes
  • Premature menopause
  • Surgical oophorectomy
  • Turner syndrome (gonadal dysgenesis).

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with complaints of inability to conceive underwent the following investigation. Which of the following is false about the same?

choices.text: The best time to perform it is before ovulation
It is perfomed to detect uterine anomalies
It is the first-line investigation in genital tuberculosis
Premedication can be done with atropine

questions.solution:
The given image shows a hysterosalpingogram (HSG). HSG is contraindicated in genital tuberculosis.

Procedure of HSG:

  • It is best performed in the period between the last day of menses to ovulation, usually on the 9th/10th day of the cycle (option A).
  • 10-15ml radioopaque dye is injected into the uterine cavity via Leech-Wilkinson cannula, Rubin's cannula, or Foley's catheter.
  • Fluoroscopy is performed as the dye passes through the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes. 
  • If the tubes are patent, the dye will spill out of the tubal ostia into the peritoneum, and smear the adjacent bowel.

It is used for the detection of:

  • Tubal block - It can be due to:
    • Strictures - fibrotic block
    • Inspissated amorphous material
    • Tubal spasm - This can occur in apprehensive patients. It is prevented by premedication with atropine and analgesia (option D).
  • Uterine anomalies (option B)
  • Uterine polyps
  • Uterine synechiae
  • The feasibility of tuboplasty, by studying the location and extent of tubal pathology.

Contraindications:

  • Genital tract infections, such as genital tuberculosis. This is due to the risk of spreading infection.
  • Bleeding
  • Suspected pregnancy
  • Allergy to the dye
  • Premenstrual phase:
    • If by chance pregnancy has occurred, it may be dislodged.
    • Thick endometrium might prevent the smooth flow of the dye, at the cornual end.
    • There is a risk of embolism and endometriosis if HSG is done during this phase.

questions.text: A pre-eclamptic patient at 30 weeks of gestation is rushed to the hospital as she suddenly lost her vision 1 hour ago. During admission, she has a seizure. Which of the given statements is correct?

choices.text: Convulsions within 7 days of delivery are called postpartum eclampsia
Thrombocytosis is likely to be found
Blindness due to this condition is usually reversible

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of eclampsia. Blindness due to eclampsia is usually reversible.

Blindness due to eclampsia can be due to a central or peripheral cause. It is irreversible only if the etiology is a combination of retinal infarction and bilateral lateral geniculate nuclei lesions.

Option A: Convulsions within 48 hours of delivery are called postpartum eclampsia.

Option B: The most common hematological finding in pregnancy-induced hypertension is thrombocytopenia.

Option D: The seizures are generalized seizures.

Note: The most common cause of death in patients with eclampsia is intracerebral hemorrhage.

questions.text: The Pap smear of a healthy 30-year-old lady is given below. Identify the microorganism seen.
questions.solution:
The organism seen in the given image of a Pap smear is the Doderlien’s bacillus, also known as Lactobacillus. This is a gram-positive, rod-shaped bacillus that grows in anaerobic conditions.

It is a part of the normal vaginal flora that is responsible for the vaginal defence mechanism.

It is an estrogen-dependent bacillus and appears at puberty and disappears after menopause.

It converts glycogen into lactic acid and maintains the acidic ph in the vagina. This prevents the growth of pathogenic bacteria in the vagina. Its absence causes a condition called bacterial vaginosis where pathogenic organisms replaces the normal flora of the vagina. In this condition, clue cells are visible.

Option B: Gardnerella vaginalis is the most common organism involved in bacterial vaginosis. As the patient in the given question is healthy, this is not the correct option.

Option C: Trichomonas vaginalis is flagellated protozoa that causes trichomonas vaginitis. The organism and the nucleus of epithelial cells appear equal in size on the pap smear. This criterion is used for the identification of trichomonas as flagella are not visible on a pap smear.

Option D: Frisch bacillus is another name for Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. It is not seen on Pap smears.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presented to the emergency room with abdominal pain and fever for the last 48 hours. She has been using a Cu T 380A for contraception for the past 8 years. On examination, cervical motion tenderness was present. What is the most likely organism to have caused her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of PID in an IUCD user. The most common organism causing this condition is Actinomyces. It has been reported in 7% of IUCD users if the device is worn for more than 2 years.

This emphasizes the need for strict asepsis during insertion of the device and the need for strict follow up of women wearing these devices.

Organisms causing PID are:

Sexually transmitted:

  • Chlamydia (most common)
  • Gonococcus
  • Mycoplasma
  • Trichomonas

Pyogenic Aerobes:

  • Staphylococci
  • Streptococci
  • E Coli

Anaerobes:

  • Bacteroides fragilis
  • Peptostreptococcus 
  • Clostridium 
  • Actinomyces (most common in IUD users)

Other:

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis

questions.text: A young woman was suspected to have bacterial vaginosis. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?

choices.text: Gardnerella vaginalis is a causative agent
Amsel’s criteria is used for diagnosis
Oral metronidazole is given for treatment

questions.solution:
The false statement about bacterial vaginosis among the following is 'vaginal itching is prominent'.

Bacterial vaginosis is a condition associated with alteration in the normal vaginal flora. There is a decrease in the number of lactobacilli in the vaginal discharge and an increase in other anaerobic bacteria mainly, Gardnerella vaginalis (Mobiluncus and Myco­plasma hominins are others organisms). It is not sexually transmitted. 

About half of the women having bacterial vaginosis are asymptomatic. Symptomatic women mostly present with a profuse, fishy vaginal discharge. It does not cause pruritus, dysuria, and dyspareunia.

Bacterial vaginosis is diagnosed by the Amsel criteria. At least three of the four are needed to confirm the diagnosis

  • White, milky, nonviscous discharge adherent to the vaginal wall.
  • The pH of the discharge more than 4.5. (pH 5-7).
  • Amine or Whiff test-Fishy odour when discharge is mixed with 10% KOH  
  • Presence of clue cells - the epithelial cells have a fuzzy border due to adherence of bacteria.

Oral metronidazole (500 mg twice daily for 7 days) or oral clindamycin (300 mg twice daily for 7 days) is given for the treatment of bacterial vaginosis. Partners do not need to be treated. Metronidazole may be avoided in first trimester.

questions.text: A 30-year-old sex worker presented with irregular menses, post-coital bleeding, and occasional foul-smelling vaginal discharge. She was advised to undergo a Pap smear. What is the best time for this investigation?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of cervical carcinoma. The best time to do a Pap smear is around ovulation, but it can be performed at any other time as well.

Prerequisites of doing a Pap smear:

  • It should be done prior to vaginal examination
  • Lubricants should not be used
  • The patient should not be menstruating during the pap test
  • The ideal time is around ovulation
  • The patient should not have intercourse 24hrs prior to the test.

Based on Pap smear findings, dysplasia of cervical cells is graded using various classification systems such as WHO grading, CIN grading, and the Bethesda system.

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

A comparison of various naming systems based on cytology (Bethesda) and biopsy (CIN grade)

WHO grade Bethesda CIN grade Description
Mild Dysplasia LSIL CIN I Dysplastic cells in basal 1/3 of cervical epithelium
Moderate Dysplasia HSIL CIN II Dysplastic cells in basal 2/3 of cervical epithelium
Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of the cervical epithelium
Carcinoma in situ Carcinoma in situ Dysplastic cells in full-thickness of cervical epithelium but basement membrane is intact

 

LSIL HSIL
Atypia confined to the basal one-third of the epithelium Atypia involving upper two-third of the epithelium
80% of LSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16 100% of HSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16
60% regress spontaneously; only 10% progress to HSIL. 30% regress spontaneously; 10% progress to carcinoma
Not a premalignant lesion Premalignant lesion
Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage

Abbreviations:

CIN: Cervical Intra-epithelial neoplasia

LSIL: Low Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

HSIL: High Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

questions.text: Suitable cases for expectant management in case of placenta previa include all except:
questions.solution:
The duration of pregnancy must be less than 37 weeks for expectant management which was advocated by McAfee and Johnson. 

The aim of conservative management is to continue the pregnancy for fetal maturity without compromising maternal health.

Prerequisites:

  • Availability of blood for transfusion 
  • Facilities for cesarean section available 

Selection of cases for expectant management for placenta previa: 

  1. Mother is hemodynamically stable (Hb >10 g% and/or hematocrit > 30%) 
  2. Duration of pregnancy <37 weeks 
  3. No active vaginal bleeding 
  4. Fetus normal on USG and reactive on CTG

Conduct of expectant treatment: 

  • Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity 
  • Bed rest or pelvic rest
  • Periodic monitoring of mother for bleeding pv
  • Fetal surveillance with USG  
  • Tocolytics if contractions are present
  • Anti-D to all Rh-negative (unsensitized) women.

questions.text: Identify B lynch suture from the image given below.
questions.solution:
Image 1 depicts B lynch suture. 

All these stitches are types of uterine compression sutures. They used to surgically oppose the walls of the uterus to arrest bleeding in case of atonic PPH.

questions.text: All of the following are criteria for the use of the following instrument except:

choices.text: Fetal skull has reached pelvic floor
Fetal head is on the perineum
Scalp is visible at the introitus without separating the labia
Rotation of fetal head is more than 45 degrees

questions.solution:
The image shows Wrigley's forceps, which is a type of outlet forceps. Rotation of the fetal head should not exceed 45 degrees for the application of outlet forceps. This is because it increases the risk of vaginal wall lacerations.

Related Pearl: Criteria for forceps delivery

Procedure Criteria
Outlet forceps
  • Scalp is visible at the introitus without separating the labia
  • Fetal skull has reached pelvic floor
  • Fetal head is at or on perineum
  • Sagittal suture is in anteroposteriordiameter or right or left occiput anterior or posterior position
  • Rotation does not exceed 45 degrees
Low forceps Leading point of fetal skull is at station > +2 cm and not on the pelvic floor:
a) Rotation is 45 degrees or less, or
b) Rotation is greater than 45 degrees
Mid forceps Station of fetal head is between 0 and +2 cm.

High forceps

 Not included in classification. Not used anymore.

questions.text: A 25-year-old multigravida at 36 weeks presents for routine ANC. On examination, a hard, ballotable structure is felt at the fundus. NST is reactive. The obstetrician performs the following procedure on her. When will this procedure be contraindicated?
questions.solution:
The procedure shown here is external cephalic version. A relative contraindication for this procedure is intra-uterine growth restriction.

Related Pearl: External cephalic version- indications and contraindications

External cephalic version (ECV) is done to bring the favourable cephalic pole in the lower pole of the uterus.

Indications:

  • Breech presentation
  • Tranverse lie

Contraindications:

  • APH due to risk of placental separation
  • Fetal causes- hyperextension of the neck ("star-gazing" position), large fetus (>3.5 kg), congenital abnormalities, dead fetus, fetal compromise
  • Obstetric complications- severe pre-eclampsia, obesity, elderly primigravida, bad obstetric history 
  • Rh alloimmunization
  • Multiple pregnancy
  • Ruptured membrane
  • Congenital malformations of uterus
  • Abnormal CTG
  • Contracted pelvis

questions.text: Given below is the partograph of a primigravida in labor. What should be the next step in managing her condition?

choices.text: Induction of labor by mechanical methods

questions.solution:
As the plotting on the above partograph has crossed the action line, the next step of management is Caesarean section.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: A mother, previously on OCPs, comes with her 2-week-old baby to the OPD. She informs you that she is currently breastfeeding her child and enquires about re-starting contraception. When would you recommend she start using contraceptives?
questions.solution:
Lactating women should start using contraceptives in the 3rd postpartum month. 

Progesterone-only methods are the hormonal contraception of choice in a lactating mother.

Efficacy of contraceptives used in postpartum period: Levonorgestrel IUD/ Implant > DMPA > Progestin-only pill.

Lactating mother Non-lactating mother
Ovulation occurs after 10 weeks Ovulation occurs after 4 weeks
Use contraceptive in 3rd post-partum month

Use contraceptive in 3rd post-partum week. 

Contraception should be ideally started after the resumption of ovulation. However, there are no contraindications for the use of contraceptives as early as 4-6 weeks in lactating women and immediately in non-lactating women.

questions.text: You have been asked to start parenteral iron infusion for a woman at 38 weeks of gestation. What formula would you use to calculate the required dosage?
questions.solution:
The formula for calculating dose of parenteral iron is:

Total dose in mg =  2.4 X (Target Hb - Actual Hb) X Body Wt. + 500 mg

  • 2.4 - conversion factor
  • Target Hb - Hb you want to achieve 
  • Actual Hb- level of current Hb
  • 500 mg - additional amount to replenish the iron stores

Iron sucrose must be diluted only using normal saline at a concentration of 1-2 mg of iron/mL of saline. It is given over 20-30 minutes intravenously.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Rhythm method is false?

choices.text: Anencephaly is a reported complication of calendar method
It is associated with no costs
Safe period can also be observed using temperature rhythm or mucous method
Abstinence is needed for about 7-10 days in a month

questions.solution:
Anencephaly is not a reported complication of calendar method.

The calendar method or the rhythm method:

  • By this method, couple is adviced avoidance of sexual intercourse around ovulation.
  • In a 28-day cycle, ovulation normally occurs on the 14th day of the cycle, but may occur anytime between the 12th and 16th day.
  • Spermatozoa deposited in the female genital tract may survive for 24 h. The ovum itself may live for 12–24 h.
  • Hence intercourse between the 11th and 17th day may result in a pregnancy.
  • The safe period is, therefore, calculated from the first day of the menstrual period until the 10th day of the cycle and from the 18th to the 28th day. An alternative method is to calculate the risk period, which is from 3 days before ovulation to 3 days after ovulation. In a 35-day menstrual cycle, therefore, ovulation will occur on the 21st day (that is 14 days before the next period) so that the risk period is from day 18 to day 24.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who presented with secondary dysmenorrhea has been diagnosed with endometriosis. Which of the following drugs is not useful in treating this patient?
questions.solution:
Endometriosis is estrogen-dependent. Hence estrogen is not used in treatment.

Treatment of endometriosis:

Medical management:

Minimal disease Moderate/Severe disease
DOC = NSAIDS DOC=GnRH agonist
OCPs (Pain with menstrual complaints) Progesterone (First drug to start)

Mnemonic to remember drugs used: GOLD GAP

  • G:GnRH analogue
  • O:Oral contraceptive pills
  • L:Letrozole
  • D:Danazol
  • G:Gestrinone
  • A:Antiprogesterone-Mifepristone
  • P-Progesterone

Surgical management:

  • Conservative surgery: Endometrial deposits are destroyed by electrocautery/laser.
  • Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA)
  • Radical surgery: Total hysterectomy with bilateral oopherectomy.

questions.text: Submucous fibroid can be detected by ___
questions.solution:
All of the above investigation can be done for submucous fibroid

  • USG is the most common investigation done. Transvaginal USG is useful to assess location, dimension and associated adnexal pathology.
  • MRI gives better soft tissue details but is not routinely done
  • Laparoscopy - If uterus is <12 weeks size and there is associated pelvic pain and infertility - to detect pelvic endometriosis and tubal pathology.
  • Saline infusion sonography and hysteroscopy are especially useful in submucous fibroids. 
  • Uterine curettage – Bump is felt in submucous fibroid during endometrial curettage.
  • HSG – Filling defect is seen.

A submucous fibroid clearly outlined during a saline infusion sonography:

Hysteroscopic view of a submucous fibroid :

Varieties of submucous fibroid:

questions.text: A 28 year old woman, suffers from emotional lability and depression, about 10 days prior to her menses. She reports that once she begins to bleed, she feels back to normal. She also gives a history of premenstrual fatigue, bloating and breast tenderness. What would be the best treatment for the patient?
questions.solution:
Fluoxetine is a Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor (SSRI) and has the greatest efficacy in PMS treatment.

Premenstrual Syndrome (PMS) occurs 7 to 14 days before menses and resolves after menses.

Treatment:

  • Psychosomatic symptoms:- SSRIs, Vitamin B1, B6 and E.

  • Pelvic pain and bloating:- OCPs and Mirena IUCD.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the image given below?

choices.text: Skin condition is characterized by thickened, gray-brown velvety plaques seen in flexure areas such as the back of the neck, axillae, inframammary creases, waist, and groin
Presents only in patients with PCOD
It develops more frequently in obese women with PCOS than in those with PCOS and normal weight

questions.solution:
The condition in the given image is acanthosis nigricans; being a cutaneous marker of insulin resistance, acanthosis nigricans may be found in individuals with or without PCOS.

  • Skin condition is characterized by thickened, gray-brown velvety plaques seen in flexure areas such as the back of the neck, axillae, inframammary creases, waist, and groin.
  • Acanthosis nigricans develops more frequently in obese women with PCOS (50 percent incidence) than in those with PCOS and normal weight (5–10 percent).

Acanthosis nigricans can also be seen in the following:

  • Obesity 
  • Metabolic syndromes (Type 2 diabetes with insulin resistance)
  • Drugs such as Nicotinic acid used to treat hyperlipidemia 
  • Sudden onset of multiple seborrhoeic keratosis 
  • Gastrointestinal malignancies such as adenocarcinoma of the stomach or pancreas

questions.text: Hysterosalpingogram was planned in a woman who presented with infertility and menstrual abnormalities to study the patency of fallopian tubes. On HSG, the findings are suggestive of genital tuberculosis.  All of the following features are suggestive of genital TB, except?

choices.text: Wedge shaped defect at the uterine isthmus
Beading and variations in filling defect
Jagged fluffiness of the tubal outline

questions.solution:
Wedge-shaped defect at the uterine isthmus is seen in patients with a history cesarean section with a uterine scar.

Hysterosalpingography features of genital tuberculosis are:

  • Rigid nonperistaltic pipe-like tube (Lead pipe appearance)
  • Beading and variation in filling defect
  • Calcification of the tube
  • Jagged fluffiness of the tubal outline
  • Tobacco-pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx
  • Golf club appearance with slight or moderate dilatation of the ampullary portion of the fallopian tube.
  • Rosette type appearance secondary to multiple small diverticular like outpouching surrounding the ampulla produced by caseous ulceration.

Tuberculous tubes:

questions.text: A 55-year-old multiparous woman who presented with chronic lower abdominal pain has been diagnosed with chronic PID. What is the appropriate treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Treatment of choice for multiparous women of older age with chronic PID is Hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy.

Related Pearl: Treatment of choice in chronic PID

Patient characteristics

Choice of surgery

Young woman

Conservative surgery or Salpingectomy or Salpingo-oophorectomy

When extensive damage precludes conservative management

and

When the patient is multiparous and of an older age group

Abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

Mild case of PID adequately treated

and

Minimal damage but the infection may lead to infertility

Tuboplasty

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for expectant management in unruptured ectopic gestation?

choices.text: Initial serum beta hCG level < 200 mIU/mL

questions.solution:
Gestational sac < 4cm is an indication for medical management of ectopic pregnancy. Expectant management of ectopic pregnancy does not have a criterion for Gestational Sac.

Indications for expectant management in a diagnosed unruptured ectopic gestation are:

  • Asymptomatic.
  • Understand the clinical implications and risks of an ectopic pregnancy.
  • Ready access to a medical facility if emergency surgical treatment is needed.
  • Able and willing to comply with close follow-up.
  • Serum quantitative beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) concentration is low (≤200 mIU/mL) and decreasing. ACOG defines decreasing as a decrease of >10 percent across two consecutive measurements.

questions.text: A multigravida who had normal vaginal delivery develops PPH. The third stage was managed actively and placenta and membranes were expelled completely. What is the first step in management?

choices.text: Insert two 14G cannulas and start IV fluids
Palpate the uterus to determine its consistency

questions.solution:
The first step in management is to insert two 14G cannulas and start IV fluids.

  • Whenever there is excessive blood loss in a pregnant woman, steps are simultaneously taken to identify the source of bleeding and to begin resuscitation.
  • If she is postpartum it is essential to identify the cause for the PPH and at least 1 and preferably more large-bore IV infusion systems are established promptly with rapid administration of crystalloid solutions while blood is made available.

questions.text: A pregnant lady with a ​history of recurrent abortions is now diagnosed to have Antiphospholipid syndrome. What would be the best mode of treatment for her?
questions.solution:
In pregnancy, low-molecular-weight heparin with aspirin 80 mg daily is the most efficacious regimen.

Aspirin in doses of 60-80mg blocks conversion of arachidonic acid to thromboxane A2 while sparing prostacyclin production. Heparin therapy prevents thrombosis in the microcirculation including decidual trophoblastic interface.

Corticosteroids are not to be used in primary anti-phospholipid antibody syndrome.

Warfarin is not used due to its potential teratogenic effects.

questions.text: The full red arrow head in the below image represents _______
questions.solution:
The full red arrowhead represents the yolk sac. The empty red arrowhead shows the double ring: outer - decidua parietalis; inner decidua capsularis.

The sign is called double decidua sign, is seen in the first trimester transvaginal sonogram. It is useful to confirm an early intrauterine location for the pregnancy.

questions.text: A woman whose obstetric score is G2 P1 L1  had an LMP of Jan 9th 2023. Calculate the EDD according to Naegele’s rule:
questions.solution:
According to Naegele’s rule, a quick estimate of the EDD using the LMP(the 1st day of the last menstrual period) can be made by adding 7 days and subtracting 3 months from the LMP (or adding 9 months and 7 days to LMP)

Here, the LMP is January 9th.

Applying Naegele’s formula, the EDD is on the 16th of October.

Less than 5% of births follow Naegele's rule. Naegle's Rule is based on 28 days regular cycle. If the cycle is shorter/longer than 28 days, corrected EDD is calculated. 

For a 35-day cycle add another 7 days (35-28=7) to the calculated EDD to get corrected EDD.

For a 25-day cycle subtract 3 days(28-25=3) from the calculated EDD to get corrected EDD.

questions.text: A pregnant female presents to the OG clinic for the first time with 8 months of amenorrhea.  On examination, uterus corresponds to 30 weeks and the fetal heart rate is 136/min.  What is the best parameter for estimation of fetal age by USG in this patient ______
questions.solution:
Femur length is the best parameter for the estimation of fetal age by USG in 3rd trimester. 

Best parameters for estimation of fetal age

Trimester

Parameter

First

Crown rump length (CRL)

Second

Biparietal diameter (BPD)

Third

Femur length

Overall

Crown rump length (CRL)

questions.text: In a pregnancy with increased Maternal Serum Alpha Feto Protein (MSAFP),  which is the next step of management?

choices.text: Repeat measurement of MSAFP at a later date

questions.solution:
MSAFP is a screening test. If it is raised, should be followed by a diagnostic test and the most preferred test is targeted sonography.

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)

  • It is the major serum protein in the embryo and fetus.
  • It's concentration increases steadily in both fetal serum and amnionic fluid until 13 weeks gestation, after which, levels rapidly decline. Conversely, AFP is found in steadily increasing quantities in maternal serum after 12 weeks.
  • Defects in fetal integument, such as neural-tube and ventral wall defects, permit AFP to leak into the amnionic fluid, resulting in dramatically increased maternal serum AFP levels.
  • Maternal serum AFP screening is generally performed from 15 through 20 weeks.

Note : Amniocentesis is a diagnostic test for amniotic fluid AFP measurement. It was once considered the standard for the diagnosis of open neural tube disorders, and now it has been replaced in most centers by targeted sonography.

questions.text: Which of the following changes does not occur in the renal system during normal pregnancy?

choices.text: Increase in GFR, renal plasma flow
Increase in amino acids and water-soluble vitamin excretion

questions.solution:
The change that does not occur during normal pregnancy is an increase in serum creatinine levels. Serum creatinine levels decrease during normal pregnancy from a mean of 0.7 mg/dL to 0.5 mg/dL.

Renal system physiological changes in pregnancy

Increase

Decrease

Renal blood flow(+80%)

Plasma osmolality

GFR(+60%)

S.creatinine

Creatinine clearance

S.Uric acid

Glucosuria

S.Na/K/Cl

Anatomical changes:

  • Both kidneys enlarge by 1.5 cm.
  • Hydroureter and hydronephrosis (more common on right side) due to dextrorotation of the uterus and relaxant effect of progesterone 
  • Congestion of bladder causing decreased bladder capacity
  • Increased bladder pressure and intraurethral pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following need intervention in a newborn?
questions.solution:
Crying during micturition indicates the possibility of urinary tract infection. This requires prompt investigations and treatment with antibiotics. 

Newborns usually cry before the passage of urine due to the uncomfortable sensation of full bladder and quieten as soon as micturition starts. 

Other options:

  • Dermal Melanocytosis or Mongolian spots is a normal finding in the new born.
  • Both newborn males and females may have engorged breasts due to maternal hormonal effect which resolves spontaneously. Newborn females may also have scanty white discharge per vaginum and withdrawal vaginal bleeding. 
  • Erythema toxicum is a dermatological condition with eosinophil laden papular lesions on erythematous base dispersed all over the body which resolve spontaneously. It is the most common rash in a newborn (image shown below).

questions.text: What is the ideal ratio of compressions to ventilation in resuscitation of the newborn?
questions.solution:
The ratio of compressions to ventilation in resuscitation of the newborn is 3:1 (90 compressions:30 breaths). Compression is done using the two finger method (shown below).

A 3:1 compression-to-ventilation ratio is used for neonatal resuscitation where respiratory dysfunction (compromise of gas exchange) is always the primary cause of cardiovascular collapse. Dysrhythmias in the pediatric age group are also most often due to respiratory insufficiency.

questions.text: A 3 day old neonate is suspected to have sepsis. The empirical treatment of choice:
questions.solution:
A 3-day old infant suspected to have septicemia should be empirically started on IV or IM antibiotics with a Penicillin (ampicillin) and an aminoglycoside (gentamicin).

The most common neonatal infection in India is by Klebsiella species. Worldwide, GBS infection is the most common cause of neonatal sepsis. Meningitis is the most common cause of sepsis in neonates.

If the neonate develops sepsis after 48 hours of hospitalization, we should suspect nosocomial infection with S. aureus and add an anti-staphylococcal agent like oxacillin, nafcillin or vancomycin (MRSA).

If the neonate has signs of necrotizing skin or mucous membrane infection, suspect Pseudomonas infection and add antipseudomonal agents like piperacillin or meropenem.

questions.text: The milestone shown in the image should disappear by_______.
questions.solution:
The milestone shown in the image is hand regard. It should disappear by 20 weeks. 

Between 12 and 20 weeks, the child observes his own hands very intently, this is known as hand regard.

Its persistence after 20 weeks is considered abnormal.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presented with focal seizures of only the right side of his body. On investigations, a subependymal giant cell astrocytoma is found. Which of the following syndromes is most likely to be associated with it?
questions.solution:
Subependymal giant-cell astrocytoma is a characteristic CNS finding in tuberous sclerosis.
