questions.text: A 3-year-old male has the following buccal mucosa finding. After three days, he presents to your OPD with a rash. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Koplik spots which are small, bluish-white ulcerations on the buccal mucosa opposite the lower molar tooth. The clinical scenario and Koplik spots are suggestive of measles. 

The virus has an incubation period of 8-12 days, after which the prodrome phase begins with mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomic Koplik spots. This follows the appearance of maculopapular rash after 4th day of fever, which begins at the face and spreads to torso and extremities. Lymphadenopathy may be present.

Option B: Leukoplakia is a benign condition, not associated with fever and rash.

Option C: Scarlet fever presents with URI with sandpaper rash is suggestive of which is caused by beta-hemolytic streptococci.

Option D: Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness associated with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It presents with fever, rash conjunctivitis but lacks Koplik spots.

Related Pearl: Viral infections associated with rash

Viral infection  Rash characteristics 
Chickenpox Appears 1st day of fever, centripetal, pleomorphic, dewdrops on rose petal appearance
Measles Appears on the 4th day over the face and retroauricular origin
Rubella Rash on day 1 over the face

Erythema infectiosum

 Rash on cheeks (slapped cheek appearance), moves to trunk and extremities
Exanthem subitum Macules or maculopapular rash
Infectious mononucleosis Associated with maculopapular rash

questions.text: A 5 year old boy was suffering from low grade fever, inspiratory stridor and barking cough for past 5 days. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the condition?
questions.solution:
Barking cough is a feature of laryngotracheobronchitis or croup, which is caused by the parainfluenza virus. The X-ray finding is “Steeple sign” due to subglottic narrowing.

The median age for laryngotracheobronchitis is 6 months to 6 years. The clinical features include barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, low-grade fever.

Management:

  • Racemic epinephrine nebulization
  • Dexamethasone-by the least invasive route (Oral>IV>IM )
  • Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (SpO2 <92 %)

Antibiotics are not indicated in laryngotracheobronchitis.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is associated with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis?
questions.solution: Erythromycin, particularly when given in the first few weeks of life, is found to be associated with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

questions.text: Below is an X-ray of an infant with cyanotic heart diease. Which is not a finding seen here?
questions.solution:
Cyanosis and boot-shaped heart (cœur en sabot in French) points towards tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) and the atrial septal defect is not a finding seen in TOF.

Clinical findings in TOF:

  • Right ventricular hypertrophy causing left anterior hemithorax bulge. 
  • Single S2 or soft P2 because of the stenotic pulmonary valve 
  • Systolic thrill in the left sternal border in 3rd and 4th parasternal spaces.
  • The large 'a' wave in the jugular pulse is a reflection of the forceful contraction of the right atrium at the end of diastole as there is reduced distensibility of the hypertrophic right ventricle.
  • There is a loud and harsh systolic murmur due to the right ventricular outflow tract (RVOT) obstruction. It becomes louder, longer, and harsher as obstruction increases in severity from mild to moderate. 
  • However in severe obstruction, especially during tet spell, the murmur becomes less prominent as the blood is shunted towards the aortic valve and not through RVOT. 

X-Ray in TOF showing boot shaped heart:

Acyanotic/pink tetralogy of Fallot: This occurs when obstruction to the right ventricular outflow is mild to moderate. The blood would flow more through the mildly obstructed RVOT and less through the VSD. Hence, there is less cyanosis. 

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on string appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or Figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text: As an intern, you are currently posted in the Paediatric endocrinology OPD where you see multiple cases of girls having precocious puberty. The condition is defined by the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of_________.
questions.solution:
Precocious puberty is defined as the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years in girls and 9 years in boys.

Depending on the primary source of hormonal production, precocious puberty can be classified in the following manner:

Central Precocious Puberty

(Gonadotropin-dependent puberty)

Peripheral Precocious Puberty

(Gonadotropin independent)

Due to the excess secretion of gonadotropins (FSH and LH) from pituitary

Due to excess secretion of testosterone or estrogen from the gonads/adrenals.

Always isosexual (appearance of phenotypically appropriate secondary sexual characteristics before age 8 years in girls and before 9 years in boys).

Can be isosexual or heterosexual (appearance of secondary sex characters of the opposite sex).

Girls 

  • Idiopathic (most common)

Boys

  • CNS pathology (most common)

Girls 

  • Estrogenic ovarian cysts (isosexual)
  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) (testosterone increases; heterosexual)

Boys

  • CAH (isosexual; most common)

Note:

Central Precocious Puberty(more common) >> Peripheral Precocious Puberty

questions.text: Wasting in a child is assessed by which of the following measures?
questions.solution:
A low weight for height indicates wasting in a child. 

Nutritional status is often assessed in terms of anthropometry

  • Low weight for height, or wasting, indicates acute malnutrition. 
  • High weight for height indicates overweight.
  • Low height for age, or stunting, indicates chronic malnutrition. This is the best indicator of long-term nutritional status in the pediatric population.
  • Low weight for age indicates acute or chronic malnutrition. It does not differentiate between wasting and stunting. Hence, it has limited clinical significance.

Note:

Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is an age-independent parameter used for screening wasting in children.

Related Pearl: World Health Organization (WHO) classification of nutritional status of infants and children

Nutritional status
Criteria (from birth to 5 years)

Obese

Weight-for-height/length >3 SD

BMI-for-age >3 SD
Overweight

Weight-for-height/length >2 SD and ≤3 SD

BMI-for-age >2 SD and ≤3 SD
Moderately underweight Weight-for-age <–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely underweight Weight-for-age <–3 SD
Moderate acute malnutrition

Weight-for-height/length ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD

BMI-for-age ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD

Mid-upper arm circumference ≥115 mm and <125 mm
Severe acute malnutrition

Weight-for-height/length <– 3 SD

BMI-for-age <– 3 SD

Mid-upper arm circumference <115 mm

Bilateral pitting edema
Moderately stunted (or) moderate chronic malnutrition Height/Length-for-age ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely stunted (or) severe chronic malnutrition Height/Length-for-age <–3 SD
Moderately wasted Weight-for-height/length ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely wasted Weight-for-height/length <-3 SD

SD - Standard deviation (from the median)

questions.text: A male infant born at 34 weeks of gestation by emergency LSCS was found to have the following finding on histopathological examination of his umbilical cord. Anomalies of which of the following systems are most likely to be found in this infant?
questions.solution:
The image shows the presence of a  single umbilical artery which is associated with an increased risk for an occult renal anomaly.

The histopathological image of the cross-section of the umbilical cord shows 2 vessels as marked, a thin-walled umbilical vein and a thicker-walled umbilical artery. 

 

The normal umbilical cord contains 2 arteries and 1 vein. A single umbilical artery is the most common cord abnormality. Anomalies are seen in 30% of cases with a single umbilical artery. The incidence is higher in twin deliveries.

Trisomy 18 is a common association.

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about cephalhematoma?

choices.text: It is usually found immediately after birth
It usually gets absorbed within 2-4 days
It is usually located on the presenting part of the head

questions.solution:
The true statement about cephalhematoma is that it may cause neonatal jaundice.

Cephalhematoma is a well-defined swelling that is contained within suture lines and does not cross them. It is not present at the time of birth and usually develops after a few hours/one day. This swelling is usually filled with blood. Hence, the resulting hemolysis leads to the development of jaundice with hyperbilirubinemia in the neonate. Some babies may require phototherapy in severe cases. It resolves within 2 weeks to a few months.

Caput succedaneum is an ill-defined swelling over the scalp that is caused by excessive pressure to the neonatal head by the cervix and pelvic walls during vaginal delivery. It presents as a diffuse swelling and is not limited by suture lines. It is present at the time of delivery. It does not require any treatment and disappears within 1 week of life. Scalp ecchymoses are a feature of this condition.

Sub-galeal hemorrhage- It is an accumulation of blood underneath the aponeurosis of the scalp (galea aponeurotica). This is also a diffuse swelling and is not limited by suture lines. It usually occurs due to rupture of emissary veins and is associated with vacuum-assisted delivery. A timely diagnosis is essential to prevent hypovolemic shock and death of the neonate.

Related Pearl: Caput succedaneum and Cephalohematoma

Indicators Caput Succedaneum Cephalhematoma
Location Presenting part of the head The periosteum of skull bone and bone
Time of appearance  Immediately after birth Several hours after birth
Cause Prolonged labor, causing venous stasis and edema  Instrumental delivery, causes rupture of emissary veins in skull
Extent of movement Both hemispheres; crosses the suture line Individual bones; do not cross the suture lines
Period of absorption 2-4 days 2 weeks to 3 months
Treatment None

Supportive.

It can cause neonatal jaundice

questions.text: Dinesh, a 2-year-old boy presented with a painful left ankle swelling and difficulty walking. In the past, he had presented with significant hematomas at immunization sites. On investigation, he was found to have haemophilia A. What is the treatment of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for hemophilia A is factor replacement therapy with factor VIII concentrate.

Cryoprecipitate is used when factor concentrates are not available. Each bag of cryoprecipitate contains 80 IU of factor VIII.

Blood components Composition Indications
Factor VIII concentrates Factor VIII Hemophilia A
Factor IX concentrates Factor IX Hemophilia B
Cryoprecipitate

Fibrinogen

Factor XIII

Factor VIII

von Willebrand factor

Fibrinogen deficiency,

Factor XIII deficiency,

von Willebrand disease
Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP)

Coagulation factors

Protein C

Protein  S

Antithrombin

Deficiency of prothrombin,

Factor V,

Factor VII,

Factor X,

Factor XI
Prothrombin complex concentrates (PCCs)

Prothrombin

Factor VII

Factor IX

Factor X 

Deficiency of prothrombin,

Factor VII,

Factor X

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the clinic because of walking difficulties. He also has progressive muscle weakness. The examination is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The finding of enlarged calf muscles and atrophied thigh muscles with a history of muscle weakness are suggestive of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). 

Duchenne muscular dystrophy is the most common hereditary neuromuscular disease. It is an X-linked recessive disorder. In DMD, pseudohypertrophy of the calf muscles occurs due to muscle enlargement by the infiltration of fat. It is weak, unlike the muscle that enlarges due to hypertrophy. Pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles is the characteristic feature of DMD, whereas the other 3 conditions mentioned in the options do not have this feature.

Clinical features:

  1. Progressive weakness with developmental delay
  2. Pseudohypertrophy of calves
  3. Wasting of thigh muscles
  4. Characteristic Trendelenburg gait or hip waddle.
  5. Gower’s sign
  6. Dilated cardiomyopathy

Treatment includes supportive management for cardiac decompensation, nutritional management, physiotherapy, and glucocorticoids. Death usually occurs by 18 to 20 years of age due to respiratory failure, intractable heart failure, pneumonia, or aspiration.

Other options:

Option B: Myotonic dystrophy presents with distal muscle weakness, proximal muscle involvement is very late.

Option C: Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), type 1 (which is most common) presents in infancy. Death occurs early. 

Option D: Myasthenia gravis (MG) is a neuromuscular disorder that is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles, due to a decrease in the number of available acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at neuromuscular junctions as a result of antibody-mediated autoimmune attack.

questions.text: The following lesion is characteristic of
questions.solution:
Image shows interosseous membrane ossification characteristic of fluorosis.

Fluorosis stimulates osteoblastic activity, fluorapatite crystals are laid down in bone and these are usually resistent to secondary osteoclastic resorption.

This leads to calcium retention, osteosclerosis, and osteophytosis. Ossification of ligaments and fascial attachments is characteristic.

questions.text: Identify the type of amputation given below.
questions.solution:
The given image is of Krukenberg's amputation.

In this procedure, the radius and ulna are split to make a pincer mechanism. It has been recommended in blind patients with bilateral below-elbow amputation or in patients who can't afford expensive prosthesis (to provide some amount of function).

questions.text: Insall-Salvati index is associated with which of the following bones?
questions.solution:
The Insall-Salvati index is used for the determination of patellar height.

It is the ratio of the patella tendon length (LT) to the length of the patella (LP). It can be measured from a lateral radiograph of the knee.

  • Ratio between 0.8 and 1.2 - normal
  • Ratio above 1.2 - high lying patella (patella alta)
  • Ratio below 0.8 - low lying patella (patella baja)

The high and low-lying patella are usually associated with anterior knee pain and recurrent dislocations of the patella.

The image below is the radiograph of the knee showing the calculation of Insall-Salvati index.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis from the X-ray shown below?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the classic 'pencil-in-cup deformity' of psoriatic arthritis with subluxation of the thumb. 

These changes occur due to periarticular erosion and bony resorption.

The images below shows the pencil-in-cup deformity in psoriatic arthritis.

Other deformities in psoriatic arthritis:

  • Marginal erosions with the adjacent bony proliferation 
  • Small joint ankylosis and osteolysis of phalangeal and metacarpal bones
  • Telescoping of digits, periostitis, and proliferative new bone 
  • Axial changes like asymmetric sacroiliitis

Psoriatic arthritis of the hands commonly involves proximal and distal interphalangeal joints (PIP, DIP) and metacarpophalangeal joints (MCP).

The image below shows psoriatic arthritis of the hands.

questions.text: A newborn baby is found to have deformity as shown in the image. Which of the following findings would you not expect in him?

choices.text: Loss of abduction of the arm
Loss of lateral rotation of the arm
Loss of sensation in the lateral 2 fingers
Loss of flexion of the elbow

questions.solution:
The image shows Erb's palsy (waiter's tip deformity). In this condition, there is a loss of sensation over a small area of the lower part of the deltoid, and not in the lateral 2 fingers.

It is caused by injury to C5, C6, and rarely C7. It is seen most commonly in babies with shoulder dystocia at delivery.

The following are seen in Erb's palsy:

  • Loss of abduction and lateral rotation of the arm
  • Loss of flexion of the elbow
  • Loss of supination of the forearm
  • Loss of biceps, supinator, and inverse supinator jerks
  • Loss of sensation over a small area of the lower part of the deltoid

questions.text: Walls of the CT scanner rooms are coated with _____
questions.solution:
• Lead is the most common agent used in modern construction to offer radiation shielding.
  • Lead aprons are used to safeguard from scattered radiation. Thickness is 0.5 mm (0.25 – 0.5 mm).
  • TLD badge (Thermoluminescent dosimeter) is used to monitor radiation dose in India. It is made up of Lithium fluoride or dysprosium.

questions.text: Hounsfield unit depends on _____.
questions.solution: Hounsfield unit is used to measure the X-ray attenuation values in CT scanning. Attenuation depends on electron density of tissue.

questions.text: Best plane for the measurement of volume of hippocampus is ______
questions.solution:
The best plane for measurement of the volume of the hippocampus is the coronal plane which is represented by the image marked 'B'.

Coronal images perpendicular to the long axis of the temporal horn should be used to determine the amount of hippocampal and medial temporal lobe atrophy (MTA).

 

Note: The volume of the hippocampus is measured in Alzheimer's disease and medial temporal seizures.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented with acute onset fever and dysuria. Urine examination revealed plenty of leukocytes with glycosuria. A CT scan of the abdomen was taken. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Emphysematous pyelonephritis refers to infection of kidneys, with characteristic gas formation within or around the kidneys. If not treated early, it may lead to fulminant sepsis and carries a high mortality.
  • CT is the best diagnostic modality for emphysematous pyelonephritis. It may show following diagnostic features:
    • Enlarged, destructed renal parenchyma
    • Small bubbly or linear streaks of gas
    • Fluid collections, with gas-fluid levels
    • Focal necrotic areas +/-abscess

questions.text: Striated nephrogram is shown by all except ______.
questions.solution:
Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (AD-PCKD) shows swiss cheese nephrogram. Striated nephrogram represents linear bands of contrast extending from the medulla of the kidney towards the cortex (on plain film urography and CT urography).

Conditions which show striated nephrogram:

  • Unilateral striated nephrogram:
    • Acute ureteric obstruction
    • Acute pyelonephritis
    • Acute renal vein thrombosis
    • Acutely following renal contusion
    • Acute radiation therapy to the kidney
  • Bilateral striated nephrogram:
    • Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (AR-PCKD)
    • Acute pyelonephritis (if it is bilateral)
    • Acute tubular obstruction
    • Acute tubular necrosis
    • Hypotension

questions.text: A patient is mute and immobile but conscious. He is unresponsive to the environment. He is known to be in:
questions.solution:
When a patient is conscious but mute, immobile and unresponsive to the environment, he is said to be in stupor.

The difference between stupor, sopor, and coma:

  Stupor Sopor Coma
Consciousness Conscious, but mute and immobile Drowsy, abnormally deep sleep, difficult to arouse Unconscious, cannot be awakened
Responds to the environment No/Decreased Responds to harsh sound, bright light No 
Responds to painful stimulus Yes Yes No

questions.text: A 44-year old businessman came to the casualty with headache, nausea, vomiting, and diaphoresis since early morning. He was diagnosed with depression 4 months back and has been on phenelzine. He gives the history of attending an office party the previous night where he consumed some red wine. On examination, his BP was 190/120. What is false about his present condition?

choices.text: The condition is less common with selegilline.
He is suffering from serotonin syndrome.
Tyramine is involved the pathogenesis of the condition.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cheese reaction, not serotonin syndrome.

Here, the patient on phenelzine (non-selective and irreversible MAO inhibitor) developed the clinical features of cheese reaction on having tyramine-rich food (red wine, cheese, milk).

Inhibition of the MAO-A isoform prevents the metabolism of dietary tyramine in the gut, thus allowing intact tyramine to enter the systemic circulation. It is taken up by adrenergic neurons and a hypertensive crisis occurs as a result of the powerful pressor effect of tyramine. 

The drug of choice to treat hypertensive crisis in cheese reactions is phentolamine. 

MAO-inhibitor with SSRI causes serotonin syndrome. Symptoms are fever, altered mental status, rigidity, hyperreflexia, and autonomic dysfunction.

Selegiline and rasagiline do not functionally inhibit MAO-A. They do not cause cheese reaction with doses used in clinical practice.

questions.text: A woman presented with a constant fear of sinning. She was unable to look at people for fear that she was offending them by inappropriately glancing. When people crossed their legs in front of her, she thought it was because she had been looking at their genitals. She constantly prayed for forgiveness for not being devout or moral enough. What is the treatment of choice for this disorder?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a woman who suffers from scrupulosity, a type of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). Scrupulous individuals are overly concerned that something they thought or did might be a sin or a violation of religious or moral doctrine. The treatment of choice for OCD is cognitive behavioral therapy, especially focussing on exposure and response prevention. 

Other modalities of treatment:

  • Drug treatment – SSRIs are the drugs of choice because the serotonergic system is involved in the pathophysiology of OCD.
  • Psychoanalytic psychotherapy
  • Electroconvulsive therapy – in chronic and resistant cases.
  • Surgery – stereotactic limbic leucotomy, stereotactic subcaudate tractotomy.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child does not follow instructions, is disruptive, interferes when two people are talking, and cannot wait for his turn while playing a game. His teacher also complains that he is excessively talkative, disturbs other students, and is inattentive in class.  Which of the following is the drug of choice for the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
According to the given clinical scenario, the child has ADHD. Methylphenidate is the drug of choice for the treatment of ADHD in children.

Treatment of ADHD:

  • Stimulants (first-line medications) - Methylphenidate (drug of choice), amphetamines. These drugs have a rapid onset of action and are well tolerated. The most common adverse effect is decreased appetite.
  • Non-stimulants - atomoxetine (norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor), alpha-2 adrenergic agonists.
  • Behavioral therapy

As of March, 2021, the FDA has approved Azstarys, a new drug for the treatment of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in patients 6 years of age and older. It is a CNS stimulant and consists of serdexmethylphenidate and dexmethylphenidate.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents to the OPD with decreased sleep, elation and talkativeness for the past 5 days. He also complains of irritability and distractibility. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of symptoms of mania occurring for at least 4 days points towards a diagnosis of hypomania.

Diagnostic criteria for hypomania:

A. Distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated/irritable mood, abnormally and persistently increased activity/energy, lasting for at least 4 consecutive days.

B. During the period of mood disturbance and increased energy and activity, three (or more) of the following symptoms have been present to a significant degree:

  1. Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity
  2. Decreased need for sleep
  3. More talkative than usual
  4. Flight of ideas
  5. Distractibility
  6. Increase in goal-oriented activity or psychomotor agitation
  7. Excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for painful consequences

C. The episode is associated with an unequivocal change in functioning that is uncharac­teristic of the individual when not symptomatic and is observable by others. 

D.  The episode is not severe enough to cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or to necessitate hospitalization. No psychotic episodes. 

E. The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication, other treatment) or to another medical condition.

Related Pearl: Mania Vs Hypomania

Mania Hypomania
Symptoms for at least 1 week Symptoms for at least 4 days
Marked impairment in social or occupational functioning No impairment in social or occupational functioning
May need hospitalization Doesn't need hospitalization

Related Pearl: Bipolar disorder

Bipolar & related disorders

Manic episode

  • Symptoms more severe
  • 1 week unless hospitalized
  • Marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or hospitalization necessary
  • May have psychotic features; makes episode manic by definition

Hypomanic episode  

  • Symptoms less severe
  • 4 days to less than 7 days
  • Unequivocal, observable change in functioning from patient's baseline
  • Symptoms not severe enough to cause marked impairment or necessitate hospitalization
  • No psychotic features

Bipolar I

  • Manic episode(s)
  • Depressive episodes common (but not required for diagnosis)

Bipolar II

  • Hypomanic episode(s)
  • Major depressive episodes (required for diagnosis)

Cyclothymic disorder

  • At least 2 years of fluctuating, mild hypomanic & depressive symptoms that
    do not meet criteria for hypomanic episodes or major depressive episodes

questions.text: A difficult airway is least likely to be associated in a patient with __________
questions.solution:
Cervical spine involvement in reactive arthritis is relatively rare. Hence, it is not a risk factor for a difficult airway.

The other 3 conditions - rheumatoid arthritis, scleroderma, and Downs syndrome are considered as risk factors for a difficult airway

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 7 cm with head in maximum extension
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

questions.text: What is the ideal line of management in a patient diagnosed with succinylcholine apnoea?
questions.solution:
The mainstay in the treatment of succinylcholine apnea due to atypical pseudocholinesterase is to continue mechanical ventilation until muscle function returns to normal by clinical signs.

Option B: Administration of neostigmine is controversial as the effects may be transient, possibly followed by an intensified neuromuscular blockade.

Option C: Fresh frozen plasma can augment the patient's endogenous plasma pseudocholinesterase activity but is not recommended because of the risk of iatrogenic viral infections.

Note: If human plasma cholinesterase is available, it can be given to reverse neuromuscular blockade.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an early sign of malignant hyperthermia?
questions.solution:
Hyperthermia is a late sign of malignant hyperthermia.

Clinical Manifestations of Malignant Hyperthermia:

Early Signs:

  • Elevated end-tidal carbon dioxide
  • Tachypnea and/or tachycardia
  • Masseter spasm, if succinylcholine has been used
  • Generalized muscle rigidity
  • Mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis
  • Profuse sweating
  • Mottling of skin
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  • Unstable blood pressure

Late Signs

  • Hyperkalemia
  • Rapid increase of core body temperature- body temperature rises by 1°C every 5 minutes
  • Elevated creatine phosphokinase levels
  • Gross myoglobinemia and myoglobinuria
  • Cardiac arrest
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient needs to undergo cataract surgery. Before initiating the surgery, the following procedure is performed. What is the most common complication seen in the procedure?
questions.solution:
The most common complication seen in the procedure of retrobulbar block is retrobulbar haemorrhage.

The image shown above depicts the technique of retrobulbar block which is a regional anaesthesia technique used in ophthalmic surgery. It involves the injection of a local anaesthetic into the extraocular muscle cone. The needle penetrates the lower lid at the junction of the middle and lateral one-third of the orbit.

Related Pearl: Complications and contraindications of retrobulbar block

Complications:

  • Retrobulbar hemorrhage (most common complication)
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhage
  • Proptosis
  • Perforation of the globe
  • Optic nerve atrophy
  • Oculocardiac reflex
  • Accidental intravascular injection of the local anesthetic
  • Trigeminal nerve block
  • Respiratory arrest
  • Acute neurogenic pulmonary edema (rarely)

Contraindications:

  • Bleeding disorders (because of the risk of retrobulbar hemorrhage)
  • High myopia (if the axial length is greater than 25 mm, then sclera would be thin which could increase the risk of globe perforation)
  • Open eye injury or penetrating eye injury: injection of local anesthetic behind the globe could increase the intraocular pressure which could lead to extrusion of the orbital contents.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man was brought to the casualty in an unconscious state after having suddenly collapsed in a railway station. As there was no pulse, cardiopulmonary resuscitation was started and the monitor showed the following rhythm. What is the next management?
questions.solution:
The ECG rhythm shown is ventricular fibrillation treatment of which is immediate defibrillation

The management of ventricular fibrillation and pulseless ventricular tachycardia is the same. Immediate chest compression is to be started.

It is of utmost necessity to defibrillate at the earliest because of the chances of survival decreases by 7-10% every minute without defibrillation.

Defibrillation involves delivering an electrical current between two pads placed on the chest so as to interrupt the disorganized cardiac activity and restore an organized cardiac rhythm or asystole for at least 5 seconds.

The energy that must be applied is

  • Monophasic defibrillator– 360 J
  • Biphasic defibrillator- 120 J

questions.text: Which of the following will not commonly present as shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image shows a dermatophytic infection in the groin region. It is not caused by Aspergillus.

Dermatophytes include 3 genera: Trichophyton, Microsporum, and Epidermophyton

  • Trichophyton infects skin, hair and nails. The species include T. rubrum, T. mentagrophytes, T. tonsurans, T. schoenleinii, T. violaceum, etc.
  • Microsporum infects only hair and skin but not nails. It contains M. gypseum, M. canis, and M. nanum. 
  • Epidermophyton infects only skin and nails but not hair. Floccosum is the only species in the genus

questions.text: Identify the skin condition shown in the image.
questions.solution:
In this image, a typical erythematous psoriatic plaque is shown with  silvery white scales. The site of predilection in psoriasis is usually extensor areas.

Other options:

  • Lichen planus: Presents with plane, polygonal, purple, pruritic, papules (5Ps)
  • Pemphigus: Presents with erosions on the skin and flaccid blisters
  • Pityriasis rubra pilaris: Presents with red follicular hyperkeratotic papules on trunk with islands of sparing.

questions.text: A patient with obsessive-compulsive disorder picks real or imagined acne lesions predominantly on the face, as given in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This given image shows acné excoriée on the chin of a male with compulsive picking of the face using nail pliers and tweezers.

Acné excoriée is regarded as a self‐inflicted skin condition in which the sufferer compulsively picks real or imagined acne lesions predominantly on the face. It is mostly seen in adolescent girls. 

Other psychiatric disorders associated with acne are: 

  • Body dysmorphic disorder - Some patients have acne as their prime symptom. The perceived acne is out of proportion to physical signs.
  • Eating disorders - reported in anorexia nervosa. Acne itself may be a predisposing factor for anorexia in vulnerable teenaged age groups who adopt a diet in an attempt to control their acne. 

Option B: Acne fulminans or acne maligna is a rare and severe destructive form of acne presenting primarily in adolescent males. It most frequently affects the trunk but can affect the face and presents acutely in association with systemic symptoms.

Options C: Acne conglobata represents a rare and severe form of acne characterized by multiple and extensive inflammatory papules, tender nodules, and abscesses which commonly coalesce to form malodorous draining sinus tracts.

Option D: Acne mechanica describes acne that occurs at the site of repeated mechanical trauma and/or frictional obstruction of the pilosebaceous outlet resulting in comedo formation. Examples include ‘fiddler’s neck’, which may occur on the neck of violin players, and is characterized by well‐defined plaques with the presence of comedones, lichenification, and pigmentation

questions.text: What is the clinical sign shown in the below picture?
questions.solution:
The image shows Koebner’s phenomenon.

Koebner’s phenomenon/ isomorphic response is the development of lesions in previously normal skin that has been subjected to trauma. If the same response is seen from the spread of an infective agent ( like molluscum contagiosum, viral warts), it's called pseudo-koebner’s phenomenon.

Any of the following can elicit an isomorphic response: physical trauma, including friction, pressure, incision and laceration, skin grafting, bites, vaccination skin tests, burns, freezing, and ultraviolet (UV) and ionizing radiation.

It is seen commonly associated with psoriasis, lichen planus, and vitiligo. Other associated disorders include Darrier’s disease, pityriasis rubra pilaris, lichen nidatus, DLE, necrobiosis lipoidica, and Grzybowski syndrome. 

Other Options:

Option A: Dermographism refers to an exaggerated flare and wheal response that occurs when skin is stroked or scratched. Dermographism is the most common form of chronic inducible urticaria or physical urticaria

Option B: Nikolsky's sign is elicited by applying firm tangential sliding pressure with a finger on lesional or perilesional skin. This leads to the separation of the normal‐looking epidermis from the dermis, producing an erosion, seen in acantholytic diseases like pemphigus.

Option D: Auspitz sign is pinpoint bleeding when scales are removed. Auspitz sign is due to the elongated vessels in the dermal papilla, which are under the thin supra papillary epidermis.

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

True Koebner's phenomenon In immune-mediated conditions

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Lichen planus
False Koebner's phenomenon In infectious diseases

Viral warts

Molluscum contagiosum
Reverse Koebner phenomenon Area of psoriasis clears and heals following injury(trauma)

Psoriasis
Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Generalized granuloma annulare

Vitiligo

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

questions.text: A concerned mother brings her 2-day-old baby to the pediatric OPD  with complaints of pigmentation in the lower back. Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition diagnosed?

choices.text: It is most commonly present in the lumbosacral region
It is due to increased melanocytes
Spontaneous regression is usually seen in childhood

questions.solution:
The given image shows Mongolian spots. The blue-grey coloration of Mongolian spots is due to arrested migration of melanocytes within the deep dermis and failure to migrate to the epidermis. It is not due to increased melanocytes.

  • Mongolian spots are congenital macular areas of blue‐grey pigmentation of varying size and shape located on the lumbosacral area in normal infants.
  • Extensive Mongolian spots have been associated with Hurler syndrome and GM1 gangliosidosis type 1.
  • Elongated dendritic melanocytes are present between the collagen fibers of middle and lower dermis. 
  • The lesions typically resolve during childhood, but may occasionally persist into adult life.

questions.text: A patient with carcinoma endometrium is treated with pelvic external beam irradiation. Which of the following organs is likely to be affected the most?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the ovary is most likely to be affected as it is the most radiosensitive organ. 

Radiosensitivity of pelvic organs is as follows: ovary>rectum>bladder>vagina. Radiation tolerance dose for ovary is 2-3 Gy whereas vagina 90 Gy. Hence, among the given options, the vagina is the most radioresistant organ.

The radiation dose necessary to induce ovarian failure is age-dependent. A single dose of 3-4 Gray can induce amenorrhea in almost all women >40 yrs of age. In young women, oogenesis is much less sensitive to radiation as compared to the elderly. 

Radiosensitivity of various tissues is summed up in the table given below: 

  Most radiosensitive Least radiosensitive
Tissue Bone marrow, Gonads Nervous tissue, Muscle fibers
Blood cells Lymphocytes Platelets
Stages of cell cycle G2M interphase S phase
Cell types Rapidly dividing Quiescent
Ocular structure Lens Sclera
Layer of retina Rods Ganglion cell layer

The skin is most commonly affected due to radiation. Stratum basalis is the layer of the skin most affected.

questions.text: You are a radiation oncology resident explaining the harmful effects of radiation to a patient. Which of the following is not a deterministic effect of the same?
questions.solution:
Mutations are stochastic effects that occur as a result of radiation exposure.

The harmful effects of radiation may be classified into two general categories: stochastic effects and nonstochastic/deterministic effects.

 

Stochastic effects

 Deterministic effects
Description These are chance effects. The probability of occurrence increases with increasing absorbed dose but severity does not depend on the amount of absorbed dose. This is called 'All or none' phenomenon. Increases in severity with increasing absorbed dose in affected individuals.
Threshold level It cannot be set. It can be set.
Examples  Genetic effect, development of cancer Organ atrophy, fibrosis, lens opacification, blood changes, decrease in sperm count, irreversible skin damage,fetal abnormalities

questions.text:
Technetium 99m labelled RBC scan is useful in which of the following patients?
  1. A 56-year-old man with congestive cardiac failure
  2. An 18-year-old boy with inflammatory bowel disease
  3. A 60-year-old woman with a positive fecal occult blood test
  4. A 20-year-old man who developed splenosis following trauma
  5. A 66-year-old woman with a solitary pulmonary nodule
questions.solution:
Tc-99m labeled RBC scan would be useful in patients 1, 3, 4. The uses of Tc-99m labeled RBC scan include assessment of the following:

  • Occult gastrointestinal (GI) bleed
  • Vascular lesions like hepatic haemangioma
  • Assessment of cardiac function in CCF and congenital heart disease
  • Ectopic splenic tissue (splenosis)

Tc-99m labeled leucocytes are used in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). 18-Fluorodeoxyglucose PET scan is used in tumors, including solitary pulmonary nodules.

questions.text: Radioactive iodine uptake scan of a patient showed the following result. This is suggestive of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given image shows low radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) suggestive of subacute thyroiditis.

High RAIU is caused due to Graves' disease, endemic iodine deficiency, and HCG-induced thyrotoxicosis.

In nonpregnant, hyperthyroid patients with physical examination suggesting nodular thyroid disease, radioactive iodine should be the initial test to determine the etiology. 

Pregnancy and breastfeeding are absolute contraindications to radionuclide imaging.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a device used to image gamma radiation in scintigraphy?
questions.solution:
A photon camera is not used in scintigraphy.

A gamma camera also called a scintillation camera or Anger camera, is a device used to image gamma radiation emitting radioisotopes. This technique is known as scintigraphy.

The applications of scintigraphy include:

  • Early drug development
  • Nuclear medical imaging to view and analyze images of the human body
  • Assess distribution of medically injected, inhaled, or ingested radionuclides emitting gamma rays
